editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Virolet.
sp.l: Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: If my wife seek me, tell her that
Designs of weight, too heavy for her knowledge,
Exact my privacy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I shall, sir.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Do then,
And leave me to myself.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: 'Tis a raw morning,
And would you please to interpret that for duty
Which you may construe boldness, I could wish
To arm yourself against it, you would use
More of my service.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I have heat within here,
A noble heat (Good boy) to keep it off,
I shall not freeze; deliver my excuse,Enter Juliana.
And you have done your part.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: That is prevented,
My lady follows you.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Since I must be crossed then,
Let her perform that office.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I obey you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Prithee to bed; to be thus fond's more tedious
Than if I were neglected.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis the fault then
Of love and duty which I would fall under,
Rather than want that care which you may challenge
As due to my obedience.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I confess
This tenderness argues a loving wife,
And more deserves my hearts best thanks then anger.
Yet I must tell ye sweet, you do exceed
In your affection, if you would engross me
To your delights alone.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am not jealous,
If my embraces have distasted you,
As I must grant you every way so worthy
That 'tis not in weak woman to deserve you,
Much less in miserable me, that want
Those graces some more fortunate are stored with.
Seek any whom you please, and I will study
With my best service to deserve those favours,
That shall yield you contentment.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You are mistaken.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No, I am patient sir, and so good morrow;
I will not be offensive.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Hear my reasons.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Though in your life a widow's bed receives me,
For your sake I must love it. May she prosper
That shall succeed me in it, and your ardour
Last longer to her.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: By the love I bear
First to my country's peace, next to thyself
To whom compared, my life I rate at nothing;
Stood here a lady that were the choice abstract
Of all the beauty's nature ever fashioned,
Or art gave ornament to, compared to thee,
Thus as thou art obedient and loving,
I should contemn and loathe her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I do believe ye.
How I am blessed
In my assured belief? this is unfeigned;
And why this sadness then?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Why Juliana,
Believe me, these my sad and dull retirements,
My often, nay almost continued fasts,
Sleep banished from my eyes, all pleasures strangers,
Have neither root nor growth from any cause
That may arrive at woman. Shouldst thou be,
As chastity forbid, false to my bed,
I should lament my fortune, perhaps punish
Thy falsehood, and then study to forget thee:
But that which like a never emptied spring,
Feeds high the torrent of my swelling grief,
Is what my country suffers; there's a ground
Where sorrow may be planted, and spring up,
Though yielding rage and womanish despair,
And yet not shame the owner.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I do believe it true,
Yet I should think myself a happy woman,
If in this general and timely mourning,
I might or give to you, or else receive
A little lawful comfort.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Thy discretion
In this may answer for me; look on Naples
The country where we both were born and bred,
Naples the paradise of Italy,
As that is of the earth; Naples, that was
The sweet retreat of all the worthiest Romans,
When they had shared the spoils of the whole world;
This flourishing kingdom, whose inhabitants
For wealth and bravery lived like petty Kings,
Made subject now to such a tyranny,
As that fair city that received her name
From Constantine the great, now in the power
Of barbarous infidels, may forget her own,
To look with pity on our miseries,
So far in our calamities we transcend her.
For since this Arragonian tyrant Ferrand,
Ceased on the government, there's nothing left us
That we can call our own, but our afflictions,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And hardly those; the Kings strange cruelty,
Equals all presidents of tyranny.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Equal say you:
He has out gone, the worst compared to him;
Nor Phalaris, nor Dionysius,
Caligula, nor Nero can be mentioned;
They yet as Kings, abused their regal power;
This as a merchant, all the countries fat,
He wholly does engross unto himself;
Our oils he buys at his own price, then sells them
To us, at dearer rates; our plate and jewels,
Under a feigned pretence of public use,
He borrows; which denied, his instruments force.
The races of our horses, he takes from us;
Yet keeps them in our pastures; rapes of matrons,
And virgins, are too frequent; never man
Yet thanked him for a pardon; for religion,
It is a thing he dreams not off.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I have heard,
How true it is, I know not; that he sold
The bishopric of Tarent to a Jew,
For thirteen thousand ducats.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I was present,
And saw the money paid ▪ the day would leave me,
Ere I could number out his impious actions;
Or what the miserable subject suffers;
And can you entertain in such a time,
A thought of dalliance? tears, and sighs, and groans,
Would better now become you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: They indeed are,
The only weapons, our poor sex can use,
When we are injured, and they may become us;
But for men that were born free men, of rank;
That would be registered fathers of their country;
And to have on their tombs in golden letters,
The noble style of tyrant killers, written;
To weep like fools, and women and not like wise men.
To practise a redress, deserves a name,
Which fits not me to give.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Thy grave reproof:
If what thou dost desire, were possible
To be effected? might well argue it,
As wise as loving; but if you consider,
With what strong guards, this tyrant is defended:
Ruffians, and malcontents drawn from all quarters;
That only know, to serve his impious will;
The citadels built by him in the neck
Of this poor city; the invincible strength,
Nature by art assisted, gave this castle;
And above all his fear; admitting no man
To see him, but unarmed; it being death
For any to approach him with a weapon.
You must confess, unless our hands were canons,
To batter down these walls; our weak breath mines,
To blow his forts up; or our curses lightning,
To force a passage to him; and then blast him;
Our power is like to yours, and we like you;
Weep our misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Walls of brass resist not
A noble undertaking: nor can vice,
Raise any bulwrack, to make good the place,
Where virtue seeks to enter; then to fall
In such a brave attempt, were such an honour;
That Brutus, did he live again would envy.
Were my dead father in you, and my brothers;
Nay, all the ancestors I am derived from;
As you, in being what you are, are all these.
I had rather wear a mourning garment for you,
And should be more proud of my widowhood;
You dying for the freedom of this country;
Then if I were assured, I should enjoy
A perpetuity of life and pleasure,
With you the tyrant living.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Till this minute,
I never heard thee speak; oh more than woman!
And more to be beloved; can I find out
A cabinet, to lock a secret in,
Of equal trust to thee? all doubts, and fears,
That scandalize your sex, be far from me;
Thou shalt partake my near and dearest counsels,
And further them with thine.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I will be faithful.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Know then this day, stand heaven propitious to us,
Our liberty begins.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: In Ferrand's death?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: 'Tis plotted love, and strongly, and believe it,
For nothing else could do it; 'twas the thought,
How to proceed in this design and end it,
That made strange my embraces.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Cursed be she,
That's so indulgent to her own delights,
That for their satisfaction, would give
A stop to such a glorious enterprise:
For me, I would not for the world, I had been
Guilty of such a crime; go on and prosper.
Go on my dearest lord, I love your honour
Above my life; nay, yours; my prayers go with you;
Which I will strengthen with my tears: the wrongs
Of this poor country, edge your sword; oh may it
Pierce deep into this tyrant's heart, and then
When you return bathed in his guilty blood,
I'll wash you clean with fountains of true joy.
But who are your assistants? though I am
So covetous of your glory, that I could wish
You had no sharer in it. Knock.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Be not curious.
They come, however you command my bosom,
To them I would not have you seen.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am gone sir,
Be confident; and may my resolution
Be present with you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Such a masculine spirit,
With more than woman's virtues, were a dower
To weigh down a King's fortune.

sp.speaker: Briss.
sp.p: Good day to you. Enter Brissonet Camillo, Ronvere.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: You are an early stirrer.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: What new face,
Bring you along?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: If I stand doubted sir?
As by your looks I guess it: you much injure
A man that loves, and truly loves this country,
With as much zeal as you do; one that hates
The prince by whom it suffers, and as deadly;
One that dares step as far to gain my freedom,
As any he that breathes; that wears a sword
As sharp as any's.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Nay, no more comparisons.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: What you but whisper, I dare speak aloud,
Stood the King by; have means to put in act too
What you but coldly plot; if this deserve then
Suspicion in the best, the boldest, wisest?
Pursue your own intents, I'll follow mine;
And if I not outstrip you —

sp.speaker: Briss.
sp.l: Be assured sir,
A conscience like this can never be allied
To treachery.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Who durst speak so much,
But one that is like us a sufferer,
And stands as we affected?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You are cozened
And all undone; every intelligencer
Speaks treason with like licence; is not this
Ronvere, that hath for many years been trained
In Ferrand's school, a man in trust and favour,
Rewarded too and highly?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Grant all this,
The thought of what he was, being as he is now;
A man disgraced, and with contempt thrown off;
Will spur him to revenge, as swift as they,
That never were in favour.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Poor and childish.

sp.speaker: Briss.
sp.l: His regiment is cast, that is most certain;
And his command in the castle given away.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: That on my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Grosser still, what shepherd
Would yield the poor remainder of his flock,
To a known wolf; though he put on the habit,
Of a most faithful dog, and bark like one?
As this but only talks.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yes, he has means too.

sp.speaker: Virol.
sp.l: I know it to my grief, weak men I know it;
To make his peace, if there were any war
Between him and his master, betraying
Our innocent lives.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: You are too suspicious;
And I have born too much, beyond my temper,
Take your own ways, I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You may stay now;
You have enough, and all indeed you fished for;
But one word gentlemen: have you discovered
To him alone our plot?

sp.speaker: Briss.
sp.l: To him and others, that are at his devotion.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Worse and worse:
For were he only conscious of our purpose,
Though with the breach of hospitable laws,
In my own house, I'd silence him for ever:
But what is passed my help, is passed my care,
I have a life to lose.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Have better hopes.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: And when you know, with what charge I have furthered
Your noble undertaking, you will swear me
Another man; the guards I have corrupted:
And of the choice of all our noblest youths,
Attired like virgins; such as hermit's would
Welcome to their sad cells, prepared a mask;
As done for the King's pleasure.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: For his safety
I rather fear; and as a pageant to
Usher our ruin.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: We as torch-bearers
Will wait on these, but with such art and cunning;
I have conveyed sharp poniards in the wax,
That we may pass, though searched through all his guards
Without suspicion, and in all his glory,
Oppress him, and with safety.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: 'Tis most strange.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: To be effected.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: You are doubtful still.

sp.speaker: Briss.
sp.l: But we resolved to follow him, and if you
Desist now Virolet, we will say 'tis fear,
Rather than providence. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And so we leave you,Enter Julian.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: To your wise doubts, and to my better counsels;
Oh! pardon me my lord, and trust me too;
Let me not like Cassandra prophesy truths,
And never be believed, before the mischief:
I have heard all; know this Ronvere a villain,
A villain that hath tempted me, and plotted
This for your ruin, only to make way
To his hopes in my embraces; at more leisure
I will acquaint you, wherefore I concealed it
To this last minute; if you stay you are lost,
And all prevention too late. I know,
And 'tis to me known only, a dark cave
Within this house, a part of my poor dower,
Where you may lie concealed, as in the centre,
Till this rough blast be o'er; where there is air,
More than to keep in life; Ferrand will find you,
So curious his fears are.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: 'Tis better fall
Than hide my head, now 'twas thine own advice,
My friends engaged too.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You stand further bound,
Then to weak men that have betrayed themselves,
Or to my council, though then just and loyal:
Your fancy hath been good, but not your judgement,
In choice of such to side you, will you leap
From a steep tower, because a desperate fool
Does it, and trusts the wind to save his hazard?
There's more expected from you; all men's eyes are fixed
On viriolet, to help not hurt them;
Make good their hopes and ours, you have sworn often,
That you dare credit me; and allowed me wise
Although a woman; even Kings in great actions,
Wait opportunity and so must you sir,
Or lose your understanding.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Thou art constant;
I am uncertain fool, a most blind fool;
Be thou my guide.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I. I fail to direct you,
For torment or reward, when I am wretched,
May constancy forsake me.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I've my safety.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Why are you rapt thus?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Peace, thou art a fool.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: But if I were a flatterer like your worship,
I should be wise and rich too;
There are few else that prosper, bawds excepted,
They hold an equal place there.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: A shrewd knave;
But oh the King, the happy King!

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Why happy?
In bearing a great burden.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: What bears he,
That's born on prince's shoulders?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: A crown's weight,
Which sets more heavy on his head, than the ore
Slaves dig out of the mines, of which 'tis made.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Thou worthily art his fool, to think that heavy
That carries him in the air; the reverence due
To that most sacred gold, makes him adored,
His footsteps kissed, his smiles to raise a beggar
To a lord's fortune; and when he but frowns,
The city quakes.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Or the poor cuckolds in it,
Coxcombs I should say, I am of a fool.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Grown a philosopher, to hear this parasite.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: The delicates he is served with see and envy,

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I had rather have an onion with a stomach,
Than these without one.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: The celestial music,Still music.
Such as the motion of the eternal spheres
Yields Jove, when he drinks nectar.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Here's a fine knave, yet hath to many fellows.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Then the beauties,
That with variety of choice embraces,These pass o'er.
Renew his age.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Help him to crouch rather,
And the French cringe, they are excellent surgeons that way.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: O majesty! let others think of heaven,
While I contemplate thee.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: This is not atheism, but court observance.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Now the god appears, ushered with earthquakes.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: Base idolatry. Flourish enter Ferrand, guard, women, servants.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: These meats are poisoned, hang
The cooks; no note more, on
Forfeit of your fingers; do you
Envy me a minute's slumber, what are these?

sp.speaker: 1. Gu.
sp.l: The ladies appointed by your majesty.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To the purpose, for what appointed?

sp.speaker: 1. Gu.
sp.l: For your grace's pleasure.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To suck away the little blood is left me,
By my continual cares; I am not apt now,
Enjoy them first, taste of my diet once;
And your turn served, for fifty crowns a piece
Their husbands may redeem them.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: Great sir, mercy.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I am deaf, why stare you? is what we command
To be disputed? who's this? bring you the dead
T'upbraid me to my face?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Hold emperor;
Hold mightest of Kings, I am thy vassal,
Thy footstool, that durst not presume to look
On thy offended face.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Castruchio rise.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Let not the lightning of thy eye consume me,
Nor hear that musical tongue, in dreadful thunder,
That speaks all mercy.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Here's no flattering rogue.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Ferrand, that is the father of his people,
The glory of mankind.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No more, no word more;
And while I tell my troubles to myself,
Be statues without motion or voice,
Though to be flattered, is an itch to greatness,
It now offends me.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Here's the happy man;
But speak who dares.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: When I was innocent;
I yet remember, I could eat and sleep,
Walk unaffrighted, but now terrible to others:
My guards cannot keep fear from me
It still pursues me; oh! my wounded conscience,
The bed I would rest in, is stuffed with thorns;
The grounds strowed o'er with adders, and with aspics
Where ere I set my foot, but I am in,
And what was got with cruelty, with blood,
Must be defended, though this life's a hell,
I fear a worse hereafter ▪ ha!

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: My lord. Enter Ronvere and guard.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Welcome ronvere, welcome my golden plummet
With which I sound mine enemies' depths and angers,
Hast thou discovered.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: All as you could wish sir,
The plot, and the contrivers; was made one
Of the conspiracy.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Is Virolet in?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: The head of all, he only scented me:
And from his fear, that I played false is fled;
The rest I have in fetters

sp.speaker: Fer
sp.l: Death and hell.
Next to my mortal foe the pirate Sesse,
I aimed at him; he's virtuous, and wise,
A lover of his freedom and his countries
Dangerous to such as govern by the sword,
And so to me: no tract which way he went,
No means to overtake him?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: There's some hope left;
But with a rough hand, to be seized upon.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: If any know, or where he is,
Or which way he is fled, it is his wife;
Her with his father I have apprehended,
And brought among the rest.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Twas wisely ordered,
Go fetch them in, and let my executionersExit Ronvere.
Appear in horror with the rack.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I take it signeur, this is no time for you to flatter,
Or me to fool in.

sp.speaker: Cast
sp.l: Thou art wise in this, let's off, it is unsafe to be near Jove,
When he begins to thunder.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Good morality. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I that have pierced into the hearts of men;
Forced them to lay open with my looks,
Secrets whose least discovery was death,
Will rend for what concerns my life, the fortress,
Of a weak woman's faith. Enter Ronvere, guard, executioners with a rack, Camillo, Brissonet Pandulfo, Juliana.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Whate'er we suffer,
The weight, that loads a traitor's
Heart sit ever, heavy on thine.

sp.speaker: Briss
sp.l: As we are caught by thee,
Fall thou by others.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Pish poor fools, your curses will
Never reach me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Now by my Virolet's life;
Father, this is a glorious stage of murder.
Here are five properties too, and such spectators,
As will expect good action, to the life;
Let us perform our parts, and we shall live,
When these are rotten, would we might begin once;
Are you the master of the company?
Troth you are tedious now.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: She does deride me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Thee and thy power, if one poor syllable
Could win me, an assurance of thy favour,
I would not speak it, I desire to be
The great example of thy cruelty,
To whet which one, know Ferrand, I alone
Can make discovery, where my Virolet is,
Whose life, I know thou aim'st at, but if tortures
Compel me to't, may hope of heaven for me;
I dare thy worst.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Are we contemned.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Thou art,
Thou and thy ministers, my life is thine;
But in the death, the victory shall be mine.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: We have such a mistress here to teach us courage,
That cowards might learn from her.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You are slow;Put on the rack.
Begin the scene thou miserable fool
For so I'll make thee.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis not in thy reach;
I am happy in my sufferings, thou most wretched.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: So brave! I'll tame you yet, pluck hard villains;
Is she insensible? no sigh nor groan? or is she dead?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No tyrant, though I suffer
More than a woman, beyond flesh and blood;
'Tis in a cause so honourable, that I scorn
With any sign that may express a sorrow
To show I do repent.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Confess yet,
And thou shall be safe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis wrapped up in my soul,
From whence thou canst not force it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I will be
Ten days a killing thee.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Be twenty thousand,
My glory lives the longer.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: 'Tis a miracle,
She tires th'executioners,
And me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Unloose her, I am conquered, I must take
Some other way; reach her my chair, in honour
Of her invincible fortitude.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Will you not
Dispatch the rest?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: When I seem merciful,
Assure thyself ronvere, I am most cruel.
Thou wonder of thy sex, and of this nation,
That hast changed my severity to mercy,
Not to thyself alone, but to thy people,
In which I do include these men, my enemies:
Unbind them.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: This is strange.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: For your intent
Against my life, which you dare not deny,
I only ask one service.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Above hope.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: There rides a pirate near, the Duke of Sesse,
My enemy and this countries, that in bonds
Holds my dear friend Ascanio: free this friend,
Or bring the pirates head; besides your pardon,
And honour of the action, your reward
Is forty thousand ducats. And because
I know that Virolet is as bold as wise,
Be he your general, as pledge of your faith,
That you will undertake it: let this old man,
And this most constant matron stay with me;
Of whom, as of myself, I will be careful;
She shall direct you where her husband is.
Make choice of any ship you think most useful.
They are rigged for you.

div.stage: Exeunt guard, with Juliana and Pand.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: We with joy accept it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And will proclaim King Ferrant merciful.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: The mystery of this, my lord? or are you
Changed in your nature?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I'll make thee private to it.
The lives of these weak men, and desperate woman,
Would no way have secured me, had I took them;
'Tis Virolet I aim at; he has power,
And knows to hurt. If they encounter Sesse,
And he prove conqueror, I am assured
They'll find no mercy: if that they prove victors,
I shall recover with my friend; his head
I most desire of all men.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Now I have it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I'll make thee understand the drift of all.
So we stand sure, thus much for those that fall. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Ley here before the wind; up with her canvas
And let her work, the wind begins to whistle;
Clap all her streamers on, and let her dance,
As if she were the minion of the ocean.
Let her bestride the billows till they roar,
And curl their wanton heads. Ho, below there:
Ho, ho, within.
Ley her north-east, and thrust her missen out,
The day grows fair and clear, and the wind courts us.
O for a lusty sail now, to give chase to.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: A stubborn bark, that would but bear up to us,
And change a broadside bravely.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Where's the Duke?

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: I have not seen him stir today.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: O gunner,
What bravery dwells in his age, and what valour?
And to his friends, what gentleness and bounty?
How long have we been inhabitants at sea here?

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Some fourteen years.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: By fourteen lives I swear then,
This element never nourished such a pirate;
So great, so fearless, and so fortunate,
So patient in his want, in act so valiant.
How many sail of well maned ships before us,
As the bonuto does the flying fish,
Have we pursued and scoured, that to outstrip us,
They have been fain to hang their very shirts on?
What galleys have we banged, and sunk, and taken;
Whose only fraughts were fire, and stern defiance?
And nothing spoke but bullet in all these.
How like old neptune have I seen our general
Standing ith' poop, and tossing his steel trident,
Commanding both the sea and winds to serve him?

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: His daughter too, which is the honour, boatswain,
Of all her sex; that martial maid.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: A brave wench.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: How oftentimes, a fight being new begun,
Has she leaped down, and took my linstock from me,
And crying, now fly right, fired all my chasers?
Then like the image of the warlike goddess,
Her target braced upon her arm, her sword drawn,
And anger in her eyes, leaped up again,
And bravely haled the bark. I have wondered botswain,
That in a body made so delicate,
So soft for sweet embraces, so much fire,
And manly soul, not starting at a danger.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Her noble father got her in his fury,
And so she proves a soldier.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: This to I wonder at,
Taking so many strangers as he does,
He uses them with that respect and coolness,
Not making prize, but only borrowing
What may supply his want: nor that for nothing;
But renders back what they may stand in need of,
And then parts lovingly: where, if he take
His countryman, that should be nearest to him,
And stand most free from danger, he sure pays for't:
He drowns or hangs the men, ransacks the bark,
Then gives her up a bonfire to his fortune.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: The wrongs he has received from that dull country,
That's all I know has purchased all his cruelty.
We fare the better; cherely, cherely boys,
The ship runs merrily; my captain's melancholy,
And nothing cures that in him but a sea-fight:
I hope to meet a sail boy, and a right one.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: That's my hope too; I am ready for the pastime.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: I'th mean time let's bestow a song upon him,
To shake him from his dumps, and bid good day to him.
Ho, in the hold. Enter a boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Here, here.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: To th' main top boy.
And thou kenst a ship that dares defy us,
Here's gold.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I am gone. Exit boy.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Come sirs, a quaint levet. Trump. A levet.
To waken our brave general. Then to our labour.

div.stage: Enter Duke of Sesse above and his daughter Martia like an Amazon.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: I thank you loving mates; I thank you all.
There's to prolong your mirth, and good morrow to you.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Take this from me, you're honest valiant friends;
And such we must make much of. Not a sail stirring?

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Not any within ken yet.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Without doubt lady,
The wind standing so fair and full upon us,
We shall have sport anon. But noble general,
Why are you still so sad? you take our edge off;
You make us dull, and spiritless.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: I'll tell ye,
Because I will provoke you to be fortunate;
For when you know my cause, 'twill double arm you.
This woman never knew it yet; my daughter,
Some discontents she has.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Pray sir go forward.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: These fourteen years, I have stowed it here at sea,
Where the most curious thought could never find it.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Call up the master, and all the mates.

div.stage: Enter below the master and sailors.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Good morrow.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Good morrow to our general, good one,
And to that noble lady all good wishes.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: I thank you master.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Mark me, thus it is then;
Which I did never think to have discovered,
Till full revenge had wooed me; but to satisfy
My faithful friends, thus I cast off my burden.
In that short time I was a courtier,
And followed that most hated of all princes,
Ferrant the full example of all mischiefs,
Compelled to follow to my soul a stranger,
It was my chance one day to play at chess
For some few crowns, with a minion of this Kings,
A mean poor man, that only served his pleasures;
Removing of a rook, we grew to words;
From this to hotter anger: to be short,
I got a blow.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: How, how my noble father?

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: A blow my girl, which I had soon repaid,
And sunk the slave for ever, had not odds
Thrust in betwixt us. I went away disgraced —

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: For honour's sake not so sir.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: For that time, wench;
But called upon him, like a gentleman,
By many private friends; knocked at his valour,
Courted his honour hourly to repair me;
And though he were a thing my thoughts made sleight on,
And only worth the fury of my footman,
Still I pursued him nobly.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Did he escape you?
My old brave father, could you sit down so coldly?

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Have patience, and know all. Pursued him fairly,
Till I was laughed at, scorned, my wrongs made may-games.
By him unjustly wronged, should be all justice,
The slave protected; yet at length I found him,
Found him, when he supposed all had been buried;
And what I had received durst not be questioned;
And than he fell, under my sword he fell,
For ever sunk; his poor life, like the air,
Blown in an empty bubble, burst, and left him,
No noble wind of memory to raise him.
But then began my misery, I fled;
The King's frowns following, and my friend's despairs;
No hand that durst relieve: my country fearful,
Basely and weakly fearful of a tyrant;
Which made his bad will worse, stood still and wondered,
Their virtues bedrid in 'em; than my girl,
A little one, I snatched thee from thy nurse,
The model of thy father's miseries:
And some small wealth was fit for present carriage,
And got to seal; where I professed my anger,
And will do, whilst that base ungrateful country,
And that bad King, have blood or means to quench me.
Now ye know all.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: We know all, and admire all;
Go on and do all still, and still be fortunate.

sp.speaker: Daught.
sp.l: Had you done less, or lost this noble anger,
You had been worthy then men's empty pities,
And not their wonders. Go on, and use your justice;
And use it still with that fell violence
It first appeared to you; if you go less,
Or take a doting mercy to protection,
The honour of a father I disclaim in you,
Call back all duty, and will be prouder of
The infamous and base name of a whore,
Than daughter to a great Duke and a coward.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Mine own sweet Martia, no; thou knowest my nature,
It cannot, must not be.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: I hope it shall not.
But why sir, do you keep alive still young Ascanio,
Prince of Rossana, King Ferrant's most beloved one,
You took two months ago?
Why is not he flung overboard, or hanged?

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: I'll tell thee girl:
It were a mercy in my nature now,
So soon to break the bed of his afflictions;
I am not so far reconciled yet to him
To let him die, that were a benefit.
Besides, I keep him as a bait and diet,
To draw on more, and nearer to the King,
I look each hour to hear of his armadoes,
And a hot welcome they shall have.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: But hark you?
If you were overswayed with odds —

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: I find you:
I would not yield; no girl, no hope of yielding,
Nor fling myself one hour into their mercies,
And give the tyrant hope to gain his kingdom.
No, I can sink wench, and make shift to die;
A thousand doors are open, I shall hit one.
I am no niggard of my life, so it go nobly:
All ways are equal and all hours; I care not.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Now you speak like my father.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Noble general,
If by our means they inherit ought but bangs,
The mercy of the main yard light upon us.
No, we can sink too sir, and sink low enough,
To pose their cruelties, to follow us:
And he that thinks of life, if the world go that way,
A thousand cowards suck his bones.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Let the worst come,
I can unbreech a cannon, and without much help
Turn her into the keel; and when she has split it,
Every man knows his way, his own prayers,
And so good night I think.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: We have lived all with you,Boy a top.
And will die with you general.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: I thank you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Boy above.
sp.l: A sail, a sail.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: A cheerful sound.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A sail.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Of whence? of whence boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A lusty sail.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Look right, and look again.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: She plows the sea before her,
And foams i'th mouth.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Of whence?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I ken not yet sir.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: O may she prove of Naples.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Prove the devil,
We'll spit out fire as thick as she.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Hoy.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Brave boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Of Naples Naples, I think of Naples, master,
Methinks I see the arms.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Up, up another,
And give more certain signs. Exit Saylor.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: All to your business,
And stand but right and true ▪

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Hang him that halts now.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sh'as us in chase.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: We'll spare her our main topsail,
He shall not look us long, we are no starters,
Down with the foresail too, we'll spoom before her.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Gunner, good noble gunner, for my honour
Load me but these two minions in the chape there;
And load 'em right, that they may bid fair welcome,
And be thine eye and level as thy heart it.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Madam, I'll scratch 'em out, I'll piss 'em out else.

sp.speaker: Sailor above.
sp.l: Ho.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Of whence now?

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: Of Naples, Naples, Naples.
I see her top flag how she quarters Naples.
I hear her trumpets.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Down, she's welcome to us. Exit mast. Bots. gun. Sayl.
Every man to his charge, man her i'th bow well.
And place your rakers right, daughter be sparing.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I swear I'll be above sir, in the thickest,
And where most danger is, I'll seek for honour.
They have begun, hark how their trumpets call us.
Hark how the wide mouthed cannons sing amongst us.
Hark how they sail; out of our shells for shame sir.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Now fortune and my cause.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Be bold and conquer. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: They'll board us once again, they're tough and valiant.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Twice we have blown 'em into th'air like feathers.
And made 'em dance.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Good boys, fight bravely, manly. Enter gunner.
They come on yet; clap in her stern, and yoke 'em.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: You shall not need, I have provision for 'em;
Let 'em board once again, the next is ours.
Stand bravely to your pikes, away, be valiant.
I have a second course of service for 'em,
Shall make the bowels of their bark ache, hoy
The Duke fights like a dragon. Who dares be idle. Exit. Charge, trumpets, pieces go off.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Down with 'em, stow 'em in.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Cut their throats, 'tis brotherhood to fling 'em into the sea.
The Duke is hurt, so is his lovely daughter Martia.
We have the day yet. Enter gunner.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.p: Pox fire 'em, they have smoked us, never such plumbs yet flew.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: They have rent the ship, and bored a hundred holes,
She swims still lustily.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: She made a brave fight, and he shall be cured,
And make a braver yet.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.p: Bring us some cans up, I am hot as fire. Enter boy with 3 cans.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: I am sure I am none o'th coolest.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: My cannons rung like bells. Here's to my mistress.
The dainty sweet brass minion, split their foremast,
She never failed.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Ye did all well, and truly, like faithful honest men.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.p: But is she rich master? Trumpet flourish.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Rich for my captain's purpose howsoever,
And we are his. - how bravely now he shows,
Heated in blood and anger? how do you sir?
Not wounded mortally I hope?

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: No master, but only wear the livery of fury.
I am hurt, and deep.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: My mistress too?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: A scratch man,
My needle would ha' done as much good sir,
Be provident and careful.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Prithee peace girl,
This wound is not the first blood I have blushed in,
Ye fought all like tall men, my thanks among ye,
That speaks not what my purse means, but my tongue, soldiers.
Now sir, to you that sought me out, that found me,
That found me what I am, the tyrant's tyrant;
You that were imped the weak arm to his folly,
You are welcome to your death.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I do expect it,
And therefore need no compliment, but wait it.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Thou borest the face once of a noble gentleman,
Ranked in the first file of the virtuous,
By every hopeful spirit, showed and pointed,
Thy country's love; one that advanced her honour,
Not tainted with the base and servile uses
The tyrant ties men's souls too. Tell me Virolet,
If shame have not forsook thee, with thy credit.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: No more of these racks; what I am I am.
I hope not to go free with poor confessions;
Nor if I show ill, will I seem a monster,
By making my mind prisoner; do your worst.
When I came out to deal with you, I cast it,
Only those base inflictions fit for slaves,
Because I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Thou art none.
Thou wast while thou stoodst good, thou'rt now a villain
And agent for the devil.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: That tongue lies.
Give me my sword again, and stand all armed;
He prove it on ye all, I am a gentleman,
A man as fair in honour; rate your prisoners;
How poor and like a pedagogue it shows?
How far from nobleness? 'tis fair, you may kill's;
But to defame your victory with foul language.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Go, fling him overboard; I'll teach you sirrah.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You cannot teach me to die. I could kill you now
With patience, in despising all your cruelties.
And make you choke with anger.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Away I say.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay sir, has given you such bold language,
I am not reconciled to him yet, and therefore
He shall not have his wish observed so nearly,
To die when he please; I beseech you stay sir.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Do with him what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Carry him to th'bilboes,
And clap him fast there, with the prince.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Do lady,
For any death you give, I am bound to bless you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now to your cabin, sir; pray lean upon me,
And take your rest, the surgeons wait all for you.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Thou makest me blush to see thee bear thy fortunes;
Why, sure I have no hurt, I have not fought sure?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: You bleed apace, sir.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Ye grow cold too.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: I must be ruled, no leaning,
My deepest wounds scorn crutches.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A brave general. Flor. trumpets, cornets.

sp.speaker: 1 sailor
sp.l: Will they not Moor her?

sp.speaker: 2 sailor
sp.l: Not till we come to the fort,
This is too weak a place for our defences,
The carpenters are hard at work; she swims well,
And may hold out another fight. The ship we took
Burns there to give us light.

sp.speaker: 1 sailor
sp.l: She made a brave fight.

sp.speaker: 2 sailor
sp.l: She put us all in fear.

sp.speaker: 1 sailor
sp.l: Beshrew my heart did she.
Her men are gone to Candy, they are peppered,
All but this prisoner.

sp.speaker: 2 sailor
sp.l: Sure he's a brave fellow.

sp.speaker: 1 Say.
sp.l: A stubborn knave, but we have pulled his bravery.
sp.stage: He discovers Virolet and Ascanio in the bilboes.
sp.l: Look how he looks now: come let's go serve his diet,
Which is but bread and water.

sp.speaker: 2 sailor
sp.l: He'll grow fat on't. Exeunt Saylors.

sp.speaker: Ascan.
sp.l: I must confess I have endured much misery,
Even almost to the ruin of my spirit,
But ten times more grows my affliction,
To find my friend here.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Had we served our country,
Or honesties, as we have served our follies,
We had not been here now?

sp.speaker: Ascan.
sp.l: 'Tis to true Virolet.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: And yet my end in venturing for your safety,
Pointed at more than Ferrant's will, a base one;
Some service for mine own, some for my nation,
Some for my friend; but I am rightly paid,
That durst adventure such a noble office,
From the most treacherous command of mischief;
You know him now?

sp.speaker: Ascan.
sp.l: And when I nearer knew him,
Then when I waited, heaven be witness with me,
(And if I lie my miseries still load me)
With what tears I have wooed him, with what prayers,
What weight of reasons I have laid, what dangers;
Then, when the people's curses flew like storms;
And every tongue was whetted to defame him,
To leave his doubts, his tyrannies, his slaughters,
His fell oppressions. I know I was hated too.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: And all mankind that knew him: these confessions
Do no good to the world, to heaven they may.
Let's study to die well, we have lived like coxcombs.

sp.speaker: Ascan.
sp.l: That my misfortune, should lose you too.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Yes;
And not only me, but many more, and better:
For my life, 'tis not this; or might I save yours,
And some brave friends I have engaged, let me go;
It were the meritorious death I wish for,
But we must hang or drown like whelps.

sp.speaker: Ascan.
sp.l: No remedy.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: On my part I expect none. I know the man,
And know he has been nettled to the quick too,
I know his nature.

sp.speaker: Ascan.
sp.l: A most cruel nature.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: His wrongs have bred him up. I cannot blame him.

sp.speaker: Ascan.
sp.l: He has a daughter too, the greatest scorner,
And most insulter upon misery.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: For those, they are toys to laugh at, not to lead men:
A woman's mirth or anger, like a meteor
Glides and is gone, and leaves no crack behind it;
Our miseries would seem like masters to us,
And shake our manly spirits into favours,
If we respected those; the more they glory,
And raise insulting trophies on our ruins;
The more our virtues shine in patience.
Sweet prince, the name of death was never terrible
To him that knew to live; nor the loud torrent
Of all afflictions, singing as they swim,
A gall of heart, but to a guilty conscience:
Whilst we stand fair, but by a two-edged storm,
We find untimely falls, like early roses;
But to the earth, we bear our native sweetness.

sp.speaker: Ascan.
sp.l: Good sir go on.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: When we are little children,
And cry and fret for every toy comes cross us;
How sweetly do we show, when sleep steals on us?
When we grow great, but our affections greater,
And struggle with this stubborn twin, born with us;
And tug and pull, yet still we find a giant:
Had we not then the privilege to sleep,
Our everlasting sleep? he would make us idiots;
The memory and monuments of good men
Are more than lives, and though their tombs want tongues,
Yet have they eyes, that daily sweat their losses;
And such a tear from stone, no time can value.
To die both young and good, are natures curses,
As the world says; ask truth, they are bounteous blessings:
For then we reach at heaven, in our full virtues,
And fix ourselves new stars, crowned with our goodness.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: You have double armed me. Strange music within, Hoboys.
Hark, what noise is this?
What horrid noise is the sea pleased to sing,
A hideous dirge to our deliverance?

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.p: Stand fast now. Within strange cries, horrid noise, trumpets.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: I am fixed.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: We fear ye not. Enter Martia
Let death appear in all shapes, we smile on him.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: The lady now.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: The face oth' mask is altered.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: What will she do?

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Do what she can, I care not.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: She looks on you sir.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Rather she looks through me,
But yet she stirs me not.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Poor wretched slaves,
Why do you live? or if ye hope for mercy,
Why do not you howl out, and fill the hold
With lamentations, cries, and base submissions,
Worthy our scorn?

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Madam, you are mistaken;
We are no slaves to you, but to blind fortune;
And if she had her eyes, and durst be certain,
Certain our friend, I would not bow unto her;
I would not cry, nor ask so base a mercy:
If you see any thing, in our appearance,
Worthy your sex's softness and your own glory?
Do it for that; and let that good reward it:
We cannot beg.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I'll make you beg, and bow too.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Madam for what?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: For life; and when you hope it,
Then will I laugh and triumph on your baseness.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: Madam 'tis true, there may be such a favour,
And we may ask it too; ask it with honour;
And thank you for that favour, nobly thank you,
Though it be death; but when we beg a base life,
And beg it of your scorn —

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: You're cozened woman,
Your handsomeness may do much, but not this way;
But for your glorious hate —

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Are ye so stubborn?
Death, I will make you bow.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: It must be in your bed then;
There you may work me to humility.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Why, I can kill thee.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: If you do it handsomely;
It may be I can thank you, else —

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: So glorious?

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.l: Her cruelty now works.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Yet wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Virt.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Wilt thou for life's sake?

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: No, I know your subtlety.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: For honour's sake?

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: I will not be a pageant,
My mind was ever firm, and so I'll lose it.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I'll starve thee to it.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: I'll starve myself, and cross it.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I'll lay thee on such miseries —

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: I'll wear 'em,
And with that wantonness, you do your bracelets.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I'll be a month a killing thee.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Poor lady,
I'll be a month a dying then: what's that?
There's many a calenture outdoes your cruelty.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: How might I do, in killing of his body,
To save his noble mind? Who waits there?

div.stage: Enter a sailor with a rich cap and mantle.

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Unbolt this man, and leave those things behind you,
And so away. Now put 'em on. Unbolt him. Exit sailor.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: To what end?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: To my end, to my will.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Nay, now you thank me, I'll do more. I'll tell ye,
I am a servant to your courtesy,
And so far will be wooed: but if this triumph
Be only aimed, to make your mischief glorious;
Lady, you've put a richer shroud upon me,
Which my strong mind shall suffer in.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Come hither,
And all thy bravery put into thy carriage,
For I admire thee.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Whither will this woman?

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: Take heed my friend.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Look as thou scorndst my cruelty:
I know thou dost.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I never feared, nor flattered.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: No if thou hadst, thou hadst died, and I had gloried.
I suffer now, and thou which art my prisoner,
Hast nobly won the free power to despise me.
I love thee, and admire thee for thy nobleness;
And for thy manly sufferance, am thy servant.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Good lady, mock me not.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: By heaven I love thee;
And by the soul of love, am one piece with thee.
Thy mind, thy mind; thy brave, thy manly mind:
That like a rock stands all the storms of fortune,
And beats 'em roaring back they cannot reach thee:
That lovely mind I dote on, not the body;
That mind has robbed me of my liberty:
That mind has darkened all my bravery,
And into poor despised things, turned my angers.
Receive me to your love sir, and instruct me;
Receive me to your bed, and marry me:
I'll wait upon you, bless the hour I knew you.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Is this a new way?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: If you doubt my faith ▪
First take your liberty; I'll make it perfect,
Or any thing within my power.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: I love you;
But how to recompense your love with marriage?
Alas, I have a wife.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Dearer than I am?
That will adventure so much for your safety?
Forget her father's wrongs, quit her own honour,
Pull on her for a stranger's sake, all curses?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Shall this prince have his freedom too?
Else all I love is gone, all my friends perish.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: He shall.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: If thou despise my courtesy,
When I am dead, for grief I am forsaken,
And no soft hand left to assuage your sorrows;
Too late, but too true, curse your own cruelties.

sp.speaker: Ascan.
sp.l: Be wise; if she be true, no thread is left else,
To guide us from this labyrinth of mischief;
Nor no way for our friends.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Thus then, I take you:
I bind ye to my life, my love.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I take you,
And with the like bond tie my heart your servant;
We're now almost at harbour, within this hour,
In the dead watch, I'll have the long boat ready;
And when I give the word, be sure you enter,
I'll see ye furnished both immediately,
And like yourself; some trusty man shall wait you,
The watch I'll make mine own; only my love
Requires a stronger vow, which I'll administer
Before we go.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: I'll take it to confirm you.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Go in, there are the keys, unlock his fetters,
And arm ye nobly both; I'll be with you presently,
And so this loving kiss.

sp.speaker: As●●n.
sp.l: Be constant lady. Exeunt omnes.

div.stage: Enter the Duke of Sesse by torchlight, master and surgeon, with him.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: You grow so angry sir, your wound goes backward.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: I am angry at the time, at none of you,
That sends but one poor subject for revenge;
I would have all the court, and all the villainy,
Was ever practised under that foul Ferrand
Tyrant, and all to quench my wrath.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Be patient,
Your grace may find occasion every hour,
For certain they will seek you, to satisfy,
And to the full, your anger.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Death, they dare not:
They know that I command death, feed his hunger,
And when I let him lose —

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: You'll never heal sir,
If these extremes dwell in you, you are old,
And burn your spirits out with this wild angers.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Thou liest, I am not old, I am as lusty
And full of manly heat as them, or thou art.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: No more of that.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: And dare seek out a danger;
And hold him at the sword's point, when thou tremblest
And creepest into thy box of salves to save thee.
O master, I have had a dreadful dream tonight !
Methought the ship was all on fire, and my loved daughter,
To save her life, leapt into th' sea; where suddenly
A stranger snatched her up, and swom away with her.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.p: 'Twas but the heat o'th fight sir. Boateswain within and sailor.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Look out, what's that?

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: The long boat as I live.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.p: Ho, there, ith' long boat. She claps on all her oars.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: What noise is that? Hoy.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: I hear sir —Exit master.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: The devil or his dam; hail her again boys.

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.l: The long boat, ho, the long boat.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Why, the long boat?
Where is the long boat?

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: She is stolen off. En. master.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Who stole her?
O my prophetic soul!

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Your daughter's gone sir;
The prisoners, and six sailors, rogues.

sp.speaker: Says
sp.l: Mischief, six thousand plagues sale with 'em;
They're in her yet, make out.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: We have ne'er a boat. En. gunner.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Who knew of this trick?

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Weigh anchors and away.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: We ha' no wind sir,
They'll beat us with their oars.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Then sink 'em gunner,
Oh sink 'em, sink 'em, sink 'em, claw 'em gunner;
As ever thou hast loved me.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: I'll do reason,
But I'll be hanged before I hurt the lady. Exit gun.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.p: Who knew of this? Trump. A piece or two go off.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: We stand all clear.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: What devil
Put this base trick into her tail? my daughter,
And run away with rogues! I hope she's sunk,A piece or two.
Or torn to pieces with the shot; rots find her,
The leprosy of whore, stick ever to her,En. gunner.
O she has ruined my revenge.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: She is gone sir,
I cannot reach her with my shot.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Rise winds, blow till you burst the air,
Blow till ye burst the air, and swell the seas,
That they may sink the stars, oh dance her, dance her;
She's impudently wanton, dance her, dance her,
Mount her upon your surges, cool her, cool her
She runs hot like a whore, cool her, cool her;
Oh now a shot to sink her; come, cut cables;
I will away, and where she sets her foot
Although it be in Ferrant's court, I'll follow her,
And such a father's vengeance shall she suffer —
Dare any man stand by me?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: All, all.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: All sir.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: And the same cup you taste.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Cut cables then;
For I shall never sleep, nor know what peace is,
Till I have plucked her heart out;

sp.speaker: All within.
sp.l: O main there. Exeunt.

div.head: Scoena prima.
div.stage: Enter Ferrant, Ronvere, Castruchio, Villo, and guard.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: You are too gentle sir. Flourish cornets.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You are too careless:
The creatures I have made, no way regard me:
Why should I give you names, titles of honour
Rob families, to fill your private houses
For your advancement, draw all curses on me,
Wake tedious winter nights, to make them happy
That for me break no slumber?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: What we can,
We dare do

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Why is your sovereign's life then
(In which you live, and in whose fall your honours,
Your wealth, your pomp, your pride and all must suffer)
No better guarded? O my cruel stars,
That mark me out a King, raising me on
This pinnacle of greatness, only to be
The nearer blasting!

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: What think you now Castruchio?
Is not this a merry life?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Still thou art cozened;
It is a glorious royal discontentment;
How bravely it becomes him!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To be made
The common butt, for every slave to shoot at;
No peace, no rest I take, but their alarams
Beat at my heart: why do I live, or seek then,
To add a day more to these glorious troubles?
Or to what end when all I can arrive at,
Is but the summing up of fears and sorrows,
What power has my command, when from my bosom
Ascanio my most dear, and loved Ascanio,
Was snatched, spite of my will, spite of my succour,
And by mine own proud slave retained most miserable?
And still that villains lives to nip my pleasures,
It being not within my power to reach him.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Time may restore all this; and would you hear
Whose counsel never failed you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Tell me no more,
I faint beneath the burden of my cares,
And yield myself most wretched.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: On my knees
I beg it might sir, vouchsafe me hearing.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Speak, speak, and I thus low, such is my fortune,
Will hear what thou canst say.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Look but on this,
Has not a man that has but means to keep
A hawk, a grayhound, and a hunting nag,
More pleasure than this King?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: A dull fool still,
Make me a King, and let me scratch with care,
And see who'll have the better; give me rule,
Command, obedience, pleasure of a King,
And let the devil roar; the greatest corrosive
A King can have, is of more precious tickling,
And handled to the height more dear delight,
Then other men's whole lives, let 'em be safe too.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Think of the mutinous people.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Hang the people,
Give me the pleasure, let me do all, awe all,
Enjoy their wives and states at my discretion,
And peg 'em when I please, let the slaves mumble.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: But say they should be vexed, and rise against thee?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Let 'em rise, let 'em rise: give me the bridle here,
And see if they can crack my girths: ah Villio,
Under the sun, there's nothing so voluptuous
As riding of this monster, till he founder.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Who's that so loud?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I am dumb: is not this rare?
King's looks make Pythagoreans; is not this
A happiness Villio?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Yes, to put to silence
A fawning sycophant.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thou speak'st truth in all,
And mercy is a vice, when there needs rigour,
Which I with all severity will practise;
And since as subjects they pay not obedience.
They shall be forced as slaves: I will remove
Their means to hurt, and with the means, my fears:
Go you the fatal executioners
Of my commands, and in our name proclaim,
That from this hour I do forbid all meetings,
All private conferences in the city:
To feast a neighbour shall be death; to talk,
As they meet in the streets, to hold discourse,
By writing, nay by signs; see this performed,
And I will call your cruelty, to those
That dare repine at this, to me true service.

sp.speaker: 1 gard.
sp.l: This makes for us.

sp.speaker: 2. Gard.
sp.l: I now we have employments,
If we grow not rich 'twere fit we should be beggars.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ronvere. Exit guard.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Thou enemy to majesty?
What think'st thou of a kingdom?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: As of a man
That hath power to do ill.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Of a thing rather
That does divide an empire with the gods;
Observe but with how little breath he shakes
A populous city, which would stand unmoved
Against a whirlwind.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Then you make him more
Than him that rules the winds.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: For me I do profess it,
Were I offered to be any thing on earth,
I would be mighty ferrant.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ha? who names me?
Deliver thy thoughts slave, thy thoughts, and truly,
Or be no more.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: They rather will deserve.
Your favour then your fury; I admire,
(As who does not, that is a loyal subject?)
Your wisdom, power, your perfect happiness,
The most blessed of mankind.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Didst thou but feel
The weighty sorrows, that sit on a crown,
Though thou shouldst find one in the streets Castruchio,
Thou wouldst not think it worth the taking up;
But since thou art enamoured of my fortune,
Thou shalt ere long taste of it.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: But one day,
And then let me expire.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Go to my wardrobe,
And of the richest things I wear, cull out,
What thou thinkst fit: do you attend him sirrah.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I warrant you, I shall be at his elbow,
The fool will never leave him. Exit Cast. Villio.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Made for ever. A shout within.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What shout is that? draw up guards.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Those ratherEn. Virolet, Ascanio, and a servant.
Speak joy then danger.
Bring her to my house,
I would not have her seen here.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My Ascanio!
The most desired of all the men, let me die
In these embraces; how wert thou redeemed?

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: Sir, this is my preserver.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: At more leisure,
I will inquire the manner, and the means,
I cannot spare so much time now from my
More strict embraces: Virolet, welcome too,
This service weighs down your entended treason;
You long have been mine enemy, learn now
To be my friend and loyal, I ask no more,
And live as free as ferrant; let him have
The forty thousand crowns I gladly promised,
For my Ascanio's freedom, and deliver
His father, and his wife to him in safety,
Something hath passed which I am sorry for,
But 'twill not now be helped; come my Ascanio,
And reap the harvest of my winter travels. Flourish cornets. Exit Fer. Ascanio.
My best Ascanio, my most loved Ascanio.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: My lord, all former passages forgotten,
I am become a suitor.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: To me Virolet?

sp.speaker: Virol.
sp.l: To you, yet will not beg the courtesy,
But largely pay you for it.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: To the purpose.

sp.speaker: Virol.
sp.l: The forty thousand crowns the King hath given me,
I will bestow on you, if by your means
I may have liberty for a divorce
Between me and my wife.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Your Juliana?
That for you hath endured so much, so nobly?

sp.speaker: Virol.
sp.l: The more my sorrow; but it must be so.

sp.speaker: Ron
sp.l: I will not hinder it: without a bribe,
For mine own ends, I would have furthered this.
I will use all my power.

sp.speaker: Virol.
sp.l: 'Tis all I ask:
O my cursed fate, that ever man should hate
Himself for being beloved, or be compelled
To cast away a jewel, Kings would buy,
Though with the loss of crown and monarchy! Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: How do I look?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: You are so strangely altered,
We scarce can know you, so young again, and utterly
From that you were, figure, or any favour ▪
Your friends cannot discern you.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: I have none,
None but my fair revenge, and let that know me ▪
You are finely altered too.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: To please your humour,
But we may pass without disguise, our living
Was never in their element.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: This Jew sure,
That altered you, is a made knave.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: O! a most excellent fellow.

sp.speaker: Gun,
sp.l: How he has mewed your head, has rubbed the show off,
And run your beard into a peak of twenty!

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Stopped all the crannies in your face.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Most rarely.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: And now you look as plump, your eyes as sparkling,
As if you were to leap into a lady's saddle.
Has he not set your nose awry?

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: The better.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: I think it be the better, but 'tis awry sure;
North and by East. I there's the point it stands in;
Now half a point to th'southward.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: I could laugh,
But that my business requires no mirth now;
Thou art a merry fellow.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: I would the Jew sir,
Could steer my head right, for I have such a swimming in't,
Ever since I went to sea first.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Take wine and purge it.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: I have had a thousand pills of sack, a thousand;
A thousand pottle pills.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Take more.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Good doctor,En. citizens, severally.
Your patient is easily persuaded.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: The next fair open weather
Methinks this Jew,
If he were truly known to foundered courtiers,
And decayed ladies, that have lost their fleeces
On every bush, he might pick a pretty living.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: The best of all our gallants, now be glad of him;
For if you mark their marches, they are tender,
Soft, soft, and tender; then but observe their bodies,
And you shall find 'em cemented by a surgeon,
Or some physician for a year or two,
And then to th'tub again, for a new pickle.
This Jew might live a gentile here. En. 2. Citizens at both doors, saluting afar off.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: What are these?
Stand close and mark?

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: These are no men, they're motions.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: What sad and ruthful faces!

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: How they duck!
This senseless, silent courtesy methinks ,
Shows like two Turks, saluting one another,
Upon two French porters backs.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: They are my countrymen,
And this, some forced infliction from the tyrant;
What are you? why is this? why move thus silent
As if you were wand'ring shadows? why so sad?
Your tongues sealed up; are ye of several countries?
You understand not one another?

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: That's an English man,
He looks as though he had lost his dog.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Your habits
Show ye all Neapolitanes, and your faces
Deliver you oppressed things: speak boldly:
Do you groan, and labour under this stiff yoke?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: They shake their heads and weep.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: O misery!
Give plenteous sorrow, and no tongues to show 'em!
This is a studied cruelty.

sp.speaker: 1. citi.
sp.l: Be gone sir,
It seems you are a stranger and yourself;

sp.speaker: 2. citi.
sp.l: You wonder here at us, as much we wonder
To hear you speak so openly, and boldly,
The King's command being published to the contrary;
'Tis death here, above two to talk together;
And that must be but common salutation neither,
Short and so part.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: How should a man buy mustard,
If he be forced to stay the making of it?
Clear all the streets before the King:

sp.speaker: 1. Citizen
sp.l: Get off sir,
And shift as we must do. Exeunt citizens

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: I'll see his glory.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.p: Stand fast now and like men,Flourish colours.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Begin the game sir,En. Castrucrio like the King, in the midst of a guard. Villio.
And pluck me down, the row
Of houses there.
They hide the view oth' hill; and sink those merchants,
Their ships are foul and stink.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: This is a sweet youth.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: All that are taken in assemblies,
Their houses and their wives, their wealths are fore it,
Their lives at your devotion. Villains, knaves,
I'll make you bow and shake, I'll make you kneel rogues.
How brave 'tis to be a King?

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Here's fine tumbling.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: No man shall sit i'th' temple near another.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Nor lie with his own wife.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: All upon pain
Of present death, forget to write.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: That's excellent,
Carriers and foot-posts, will be arrant rebels.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: No character, or stamp that may deliver
This man's intention, to that man i'th' country.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Nay, an you cut off, after my hearty commendations
Your friend and Oliver. No more.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: No man smile,
And wear a face of mirth; that fellows coming,
And hides a double heart, he's your prize, smoke him.

div.stage: Enter Virolet, Ronvero, Ascanio, and Martia, passing over.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: What base abuse is this? Ha? 'tis her face sure,
My prisoners with her too? by heaven wild whore
Now is my time.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Do what you will.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Stay hold yet,
My country shall be served first, let her go,
We'll have an hour for her to make her tremble.
Now show yourselves, and bless you with your valours.

sp.speaker: Guard
sp.p: Here's a whole plump of rogues. Virolet and they off again.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Now for your country.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Away with 'em and hang 'em; no, no mercy,
I say no mercy.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Be it so upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Treason, treason, treason.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Cut the slaves to gigots.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Down with the bull-beefs.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Hold, hold, I command you — look here

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: A miserable thing. I am no King sir.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Sirrah, your fool's face has preserved your life.
Wear no more Kings coats, you have scaped a scouring.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Is't not the King.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: No, 'tis a prating rascal,
The puppy makes him mirth.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Yes sir, I am a puppy.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: I beseech you let me hang him,
I'll do't in my belt straight.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: As you are honourable,
It is enough you may hang me.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: I'll hang a squib at's tail
That shall blow both his buttocks, like a petard.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Do any thing.
But do not kill me gentlemen. Enter citizen.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Let's flay him, and have him fly blown.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Away, and save your lives.
The King himself is cunning on ▪ if you stay,
You are lost for ever; let not so much nobleness
Wilfully perish.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: How near?

sp.speaker: 2. Citizen
sp.p: He's here behind you. Ex. Sess. Boatsw. Saylers, citizens.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: We thank you.Vanish.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Double the guards and take in men that dare,
These slaves are frighted; where are the proud rebels,
To what protection fled, what villain leads 'em?
Under our nose disturb our rest?

sp.speaker: Ronver.
sp.l: We shall hear,
For such a search I have sent, to hunt the traitors.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Yet better men I say, we stand too open:
How now Castruchio? how do you like our glory?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I must confess, 'twas somewhat more than my match sir;
This open glory agrees not with my body,
But if it were ith' castle, or some strength,
Where I might have my swing.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: You have been swinged brother;
How these delights have tickled you? you itch yet;
Will you walk out again in pomp?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Good fool.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: These rogues must be rebuked, they are too saucy,
These peremptory knaves. Will you walk out sir,
And take the remnant of your coronation?
The people stay to see it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Do not vex him;
Has grief enough in's bones; you shall to th' citadel,
And like myself command, there use your pleasure,
But take heed to your person.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: The more danger;
Still the more honour brother.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: If I reign not then,
And like a King, and thou shalt know it fool,
And thou shalt feel it fool.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Fool's still are freemen,
I'll sue for a protection, till thy reign's out.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The people have abused the liberty
I late allowed, I now proclaim it straighter,
No men shall walk together, nor salute;
For they that do shall die.

sp.speaker: Ronver.
sp.l: You hit the right sir;
That liberty cut off, you are free from practice.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Renew my guards.

sp.speaker: Ronver.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And keep strict watches;
One hour of joy I ask.

sp.speaker: Ronver.
sp.l: You shall have many. Exeunt. Flor. Cor.

div.stage: Pandulfo, and Juliana, led by two of the guard, as not yet fully recovered.

sp.speaker: 1. Guard.
sp.l: You are now at liberty, in your own house lady,
And here our charge takes end.

sp.speaker: Pandul.
sp.l: 'Tis now a custom.
We must even woo those men deserve worst of us,
And so we thank your labours; there's to drink,
For that, and mischief are your occupations;
And to mean well to no man, you chiefest harvests.

sp.speaker: 2. Gard.
sp.l: You give liberally; we hope sir, ere't be long,
To be oftener acquainted with your bounty,
And so we leave you.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Do, for I dote not on ye;

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But where's my husband? what should I do here?
Or what share have I in this joy, called liberty,
Without his company? Why did you flatter me,
And tell me he was returned, his service honoured?

sp.speaker: 1. Gard.
sp.l: He is so, and stands high in the King's favour,
His friends redeemed, and his own liberty,
From which yours is derived, confirmed; his service,
To his own wish rewarded: so farewell lady. Ex. guard.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Go persecute the good, and hunt ye hellhounds;
Ye leeches of the time, suck till ye burst slaves;
How does my girl?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Weak yet, but full of comfort;

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Sit down, and take some rest;

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My heart's whole father;
That joys, and leaps, to hear my Virolet,
My dear, my life, has conquered his afflictions.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Those rude hands, and that bloody will that did this,
That durst upon thy tender body print
These characters of cruelty; hear me heaven.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O sir be sparing.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: I'll speak it, though I burst;
And though the air had ears, and served the tyrant,
Out it should go: oh hear me thou great justice;
The miseries, that wait upon their mischiefs,
Let them be numberless, and no eye pity
Them when their souls are loaden, and in labour,
And wounded through, and through, with guilt and horror,
As mine is now with grief; let men laugh at 'em
Then, when their monstrous sins, like earthquakes, shake 'em;
And those eyes, that forgotten heaven would look upward,
The bloody alarms, of the conscience beating,
Let mercy fly, and day struck into darkness,
Leave their blind souls, to hunt out their own horrors.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Enough, enough, we must forget dear father;
For then we are glorious forms of heaven; and live,
When we can suffer, and as soon forgive.
But where's my lord? methinks I have seen this house,
And have been in't before.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Thine own house jewel.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Mine, without him? or his, without my company?
I think it cannot be; it was not wont father.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Some business with the King (Let it be good heaven)
Retains him sure. Enter boy.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It must be good and noble,
For all men that he treats with taste of virtue;
His words and actions are his own; and honour's
Not bought, nor compelled from him.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Here's the boy.
He can confirm us more, how sad the child looks?
Come hither Lucio; how, and where's thy master?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Speak gentle boy.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Is he returned in safety?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: If not, and that thou knowest is miserable,
Our hopes and happiness declined for ever;
Study a sorrow, excellent as thy master,
Then if thou canst live, leave us.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Noble madam,
My lord is safe returned, safe to his friends, and fortune,
Safe to his country, entertained with honour,
Is here within the house.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Do not mock me.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: But such a melancholy hangs on his mind,
And in his eyes inhabit such sad shadows;
But what the cause is —

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Go tell him we are here boy,
There must be no cause now.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Hast thou forgotten me?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: No, noblest lady.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Tell him I am here,
Tell him his wife is here, sound my name to him,
And thou shalt see him start; speak Juliana,
And like the sun that labours through a tempest,
How suddenly he will disperse his sadness?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Go I command thee instantly,
And charge him on his duty.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: On his love boy:
I would fain go to him.
