sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Away, away, you are foolish.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Bear all my service sweet boy.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Art thou here still?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And tell him what thou wilt that shall become thee.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Ith' house; and know we are here. Ex. boy.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No, no, he did not;
I warrant you he did not: could you think
His love had less than wings, had he but seen me;
His strong affection any thing but fire
Consuming all weak lets, and rubs before it,
Till he had met my flame, and made one body?
If ever heavens high blessings met in one man,
And there erected to their holy uses ▪
A sacred mind, fit for their services,
Built all of polished honour, 'twas in this man:
Misdoubt him not.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: I know he's truly noble;
But why this sadness, when the general cause
Requires a jubilee of joy?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I know not. Enter Virolet, and boy.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Pray heaven you find it not.

sp.speaker: Jul
sp.l: I hope I shall not:
Oh here he comes, and with him all my happiness;
He stays and thinks, we may be too unmannerly;
Pray give him leave.They stand off.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: I do not like this sadness.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: O hard condition of my misery!
Unheard of plagues! when to behold that woman,
That chaste and virtuous woman, that preserved me,
That pious wife, wedded to my afflictions,
Must be more terrible than all my dangers.
O fortune, thou hast robbed men of my making,
The noble building of a man, demolished,
And flung me headlong, on a sin so base
Man and mankind contemn; even beasts abhor it,
A sin more dull than drink, a shame beyond it;
So foul, and far from faith; I dare not name it,
But it will cry itself out, loud ingratitude.
Your blessing sir.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: You have it in abundance;
So is our joy, to see you safe.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: My dear one;

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Has not forgotten me yet: oh take me to you sir.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Must this be added to increase my misery,
That she must weep for joy, and lose that goodness?
My Juliana, even the best of women,
Of wives the perfectest, let me speak this,
And with a modesty declare thy virtues,
Chaster than crystal, on the Scythian cliffs
The more the proud winds court, the more the purer.
Sweeter in thy obedience, than a sacrifice;
And in thy mind a saint, that even yet living,
Producest miracles, and women daily
With crooked and tame souls creep to thy goodness,
Which having touched at, they become examples.
The fortitude of all their sex, is fable
Compared to thine; and they that filled up glory,
And admiration, in the age behind us,
Out of their celebrated urns, are started,
To stare upon the greatness of thy spirit;
Wondering what new martyr heaven has begotten,
To fill the times with truth, and ease their storeys:
Being all these, and excellent in beauty,
(For noble things dwell in the noblest buildings)
Thou hast undone thy husband, made him wretched,
A miserable man, my Juliana,
Thou hast made thy Virolet.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Now goodness keep me;
Oh! my dear lord.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: She wrong you? what's the meaning?
Weep not, but speak, I charge you on obedience;
Your father charges you; she make you miserable?
That you yourself confess.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I do, that kills me;
And far less I have spoke her ▪ than her merit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It is some sin of weakness, or of ignorance?
For sure my will —

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: No, 'tis a sin of excellence:
Forgive me heaven, that I profane thy blessings:
Sit still; I'll show you all. Exit Virolet.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: What means this madness?
For sure there is no taste of right man in it;
Grieves he our liberty, our preservation?
Or has the greatness of the deed he has done,
Made him forget, for whom, and how he did it,
And looking down upon us, scorn the benefit?
Well Virolet if thou beest proud, or treacherous

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: He cannot sir, he cannot; he will show us,
And with that reason ground his words.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: He comes. Enter Virolet, Martia, Ronver.
What masque is this? what admirable beauty?
Pray heaven his heart be true.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A goodly woman.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Tell me my dear; and tell me without flattery,
As you are nobly honest, speak the truth;
What think you of this lady?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: She is most excellent.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Might not this beauty tell me that it's a sweet one,
Without more setting off, as now it is,
Thanking no greater mistress then mere nature?
Stagger a constant heart?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: She is full of wonder;
But yet; yet Virolet.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Pray; by your leave sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: She would amaze:

sp.speaker: Vir
sp.l: O! would she so? I thank you;
Say to this beauty, she have all additions,
Wealth, noble birth.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: O hold there.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: All virtues,
A mind, as full of candour as the truth is,
Ay, and a loving lady.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: She must needs
(I am bound in conscience to confess) deserve much.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Nay, say beyond all these, she be so pious,
That even on slaves condemned she shower her benefits,
And melt their stubborn bolts with her soft pity,
What think you then?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: For such a noble office,
At these years, I should dote myself; take heed boy,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: If you be he, that have received these blessings,
And this the lady: love her, honour her;
You cannot do too much, to show your gratitude,
Your greatest service will show off too slender.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: This is the lady; lady of that bounty,
That wealth, that noble name, that all I spoke of:
The prince Ascaino and myself, the slaves
Redeemed, brought home, still guarded by her goodness,
And of our liberties you taste the sweetness;
Even you she has preserved too, lengthened your lives.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And what reward do you purpose? it must be a main one;
If love will do it we'll all, so love her, serve her.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: It must be my love.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Mine, my only love,
My everlasting love:

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Pray have patience.
The recompense she asked, and I have rendered.
Was to become her husband: than I vowed it,
And since I have made it good.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Thou durst not.

sp.speaker: Virol.
sp.l: Done sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Be what you please, his happiness yet stays with me,
You have been mine; o my unhappy fortune.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Nay, break and die;

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It cannot yet: I must live,
Till I see this man, blessed in his new love,
And then:

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: What hast thou done? thou base one tell me,
Thou barren thing of honesty, and honour;
What hast thou wrought? Is not this she, look on her,
Look on her, with the eyes of gratitude,
And whip thy false tears off; is not this she,
That three times on the rack, to guard thy safety,
When thou stoodst lost, and naked to the tyrant;
Thy aged father here, that shames to know thee tyrant,
Engaged ith' jaws of danger; was not this she,
That then gave up her body to the torture?
That tender body, that the wind sings through;
And three times, when her sinews, cracked and tortured,
The beauties of her body turned to ruins,
Even then, within her patient heart, she locked thee;
Then hid thee from the tyrant; then preserved thee;
And canst thou be that slave?

sp.speaker: Martia.
sp.l: This was but duty;
She did it for her husband, and she ought it;
She has had the pleasure of him, many an hour;
And if one minute's pain cannot be suffered;
Mine was above all these, a nobler venture,
I speak it boldly, for I lost a father.
He has one still; I left my friends, he has many;
Exposed my life, and honour to a cruelty,
That if it had seized on me, racks and tortures,
Alas, they are triumphs to it: and had it hit,
For this man's love, it should have showed a triumph,
Twice lost, I freed him; Rossana lost before him,
His fortunes with him; and his friends behind him:
Twice was I racked myself for his deliverance,
In honour first and name, which was a torture
The hangman never heard of; next at sea,
In our escape, where the proud waves took pleasure
To toss my little boat up like a bubble,
Then like meteor in the air he hung,
Then catched, and hug him in the depth of darkness;
The cannon from my incensed father's ship,
Ringing our knell, and still as we peeped upward,
Beating the raging surge, with fire and bullet,
And I stood fixed for this man's sake, and scorned it;
Compare but this:

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: 'Tis too true; oh my fortune!
That I must equally be bound to either:

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You have the better, and the nobler lady;
And now I am forced, a lover of her goodness.
And so far have you wrought for his deliverance,
That is my lord, so lovingly and nobly,
That now methinks I stagger in my title.
But how with honesty? for I am poor lady,
In all my duteous service but your shadow,
Yet would be just; how with fair fame and credit,
I may go off; I would not be a strumpet:
Oh my dear sir you know:

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: O truth, thou knowest too.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Nor have the world suspect, I fell to mischief.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: Take you no care for that, here's that has done it;
A fair divorce, 'tis honest too.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: The devil,
Honest? to put her off.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: Most honest sir,
And in this point, most strong.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: The cause, the cause sir?

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: A just cause too.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: As any is in hell, lawyer.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: For barrenness, she never brought him children.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Why art not thou divorced? thou canst not get 'em;
Thy neighbours, thy rank neighbours: oh base juggling,
Is she not young?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Women at more years sir,
Have met that blessing ▪ 'tis in heaven's high power.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: You never can have any:

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Why quick lawyer?
My philosophical lawyer.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: The rack has spoiled her
The distentions of those parts, hath stopped all fruitfulness.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: O I could curse.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And am I grown so miserable,
That mine own pity must make me wretched?
No cause against me, but my love and duty?
Farewell sir ▪ like obedience, thus I leave you,
My long farewell: I do not grudge, I grieve sir,
And if that be offensive, I can die,
And than you fairly free: good lady love him;
You have a noble, and an honest gentleman,
I ever found him so, the world has spoke him;
And let it be your part still to deserve him:
Love him no less than I have done; and serve him,
And heaven shall bless you; you shall bless my ashes;
I give you up the house; the name of wife,
Honour, and all respect I borrowed from him,
And to my grave I turn: one farewell more;
Nothing divide your loves, not want of children,
Which I shall pray against, and make you fruitful;
Grow like two equal flames, rise high and glorious;
And in your honoured age, burn out together:
To all I know, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ronver.
sp.l: Be not so grieved lady;
A nobler fortune.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Away thou parasite.
Disturb not my sad thoughts; I hate thy greatness.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: I hate not you; I am glad she's off these hinges,
Come, let's pursue. Exit Ronver. and law.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: If I had breath to curse thee;
Or could my great heart utter; farewell villain,
Thy house, nor face again. Exit Pand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let 'em all go.
And now let us rejoice; now freely take me,
And now embrace me Virolet; give the rites
Of a brave husband to his love.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I'll take my leave too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How, take you leave too?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: The house is furnished for you;
You are mistress, may command.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Will you to bed sir?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: As soon to hell, to any thing I hate most;
You must excuse me, I have kept my word.
You are my wife, you now enjoy my fortune,
Which I have done to recompense your bounty:
But to yield up those chaste delights and pleasures,
Which are not mine, but my first vows.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You jest.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You will not find it so, to give you those;
I have divorced, and lost with Juliana,
And all fires of that nature.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Are you a husband;

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: To question hers, and satisfy your flames,
That held an equal beauty, equal bounty.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Good heaven forgive; no, no, the strict forbearance,
Of all those joys, like a full sacrifice,
I offer to the sufferings of my first love;
Honour, and wealth, attendance, state, all duty,
Shall wait upon your will, to make you happy;
But my afflicted mind, you must give leave lady;
My weary trunk must wander.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Not enjoy me?
Go from me too?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: For ever thus I leave you;
And how so e'er I fare, live you still happy. Exit Virol.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Since I am scorned, I'll hate thee, scorn thy gifts too;
Thou miserable fool, thou fool to pity;
And such a rude, demolished thing, I'll leave thee,
In my revenge: for foolish love, farewell now,
And anger, and the spite of woman enter,
That all the world shall say, that read this story,
My hate, and not my love, begotten my glory.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: He that fears death, or tortures, let him leave me.
The stops that we have met with, crown our conquest:
Common attempts are fit for common men;
The rare, the rarest spirits. Can we be daunted?
We that have smiled at sea at certain ruins,
Which men on shore; but hazarded would shake at
We that have lived free, in despite of fortune,
Laughed at the outstretched arm of tyranny,
As still too short to reach us, shall we faint now?
No my brave mates, I know your fiery temper,
And that you can, and dare, as much as men:
Calamity, that severs worldly friendships,
Could ne'er divide us, you are still the same;
The constant followers of my banished fortunes;
The instruments of my revenge; the hands
By which I work, and fashion all my projects.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: And such we will be ever.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: 'Slight sir, cram me
Into a canon's mouth, and shoot me at
Proud Ferrand's head; may only he fall with me,
My life I rate at nothing.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Could I but get,
Within my sword's length of him; and if then
He scape me, may th'account of all his sins
Be added unto mine.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: 'Tis not to die sir,
But to die unrevenged, that staggers me:
For were your ends served, and our country free,
We would fall willing sacrifices.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: To rise up,
Most glorious martyrs.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: But the reason why
We wear these shapes?

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Only to get access:
Like honest men, we never shall approach him,
Such are his fears, but thus attired like Switzers,
And fashioning our language to our habits;
Bold, bloody, desperate, we may be admitted
Among his guard. But if this fail, I'll try
A thousand others, out do Proteus
In various shapes, but I will reach his heart.
And seal my anger on't. Enter Ronero and the guard.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: The lord Ronero.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Shall we begin with him?

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: He is not ripe yet,
Nor fit to fall: as you see me begin,
Withal care imitate.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: We are instructed.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Would we were at it once.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Keep a strict watch,
And let the guards be doubled, this last night
The King had fearful dreams.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: 'Tis a good omen
To our attempts.

sp.speaker: Roner.
sp.l: What men are these? What seek you?

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Employment.

sp.speaker: Roner.
sp.l: Of what nature?

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: We are soldiers;
We have seen towns and churches set on fire;
The kennels running blood, coy virgins ravished;
The altars ransacked, and the holy relics,
Yea, and the saints themselves, made lawful spoils,
Unto the conquerors: but these good days are past,
And we made beggars, by this idle peace,
For want of action. I am sir no stranger
To the government of this state, I know the King
Needs men, that only do what he commands,
And search no further: 'tis the profession
Of all our nation, to serve faithfully,
Where they're best paid: and if you entertain us,
I do not know the thing you can command,
Which we'll not put in act.

sp.speaker: Roner.
sp.l: A goodly parsonage.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: And if you have an enemy, or so
That you would have dispatched.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: They are here, can fit you.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Or if there be an itch, though to a man,

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: You shall tie
Our consciences in your purse-strings.

sp.speaker: Roner.
sp.l: Gentlemen,
I like your freedom: I am now in haste,
But wait for my return. I like the rascals,
They may be useful.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: We'll attend you sir:

sp.speaker: Roner.
sp.l: Do; and be confident, of entertainment;
I hope ye will deserve it. Exit Roner. and guard.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: O, no doubt sir:
Thus far we are prosperous; we'll be his guard,
Till tyranny and pride find full reward:Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: My blessing? no; a father's heavy curse,
Pursue, and overtake him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Gentle sir.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: My name, and family; end in myself
Rather then live in him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Dear sir forbear,
A father's curses, hit far off, and kill too.
And like a murthering-piece aims not at one,
But all that stand within the dangerous level.
Some bullet may return upon yourself too,
Though against nature, if you still go on
In this unnatural course.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Thou art not made
Of that same stuff as other women are:
Thy injuries would teach patience to blaspheme;
Yet still thou art a dove.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I know not malice, but like an innocent, suffer.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: More miraculous!
He have a woman chronicled, and for goodness,
Which is the greatest wonder. Let me see,
I have no son to inherit after me;
Him I disclaim.
What then? He make thy virtues my sole heir;
Thy story I'll have written, and in gold to;
In prose and verse, and by the ablest doers:
A word or two of a kind stepfather
He have put in, good Kings and Queens shall buy it.
And if the actions of ill great women,
And of the modern times too, are remembered,
That have undone their husbands, and their families,
What will our story do? It shall be so,
And I will straight about it. Exit Pand.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Such as love
Goodness for glory, have it for reward;
I love mine for itself: let innocence
Be written on my tomb, though never so humble,
'Tis all I am ambitious of. But I
Forget my vows.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Before me, you are not modest,
Nor is this courtlike. Would you take it well,
If she should rudely press into your clolst,
When from your several boxes you choose paint,
To make a this day's face with?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Pray know her pleasure first.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: To whom speak you boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Your ladyship's pardon. That proud lady thief,
That stole away my lord from your embraces,
(Wrinkles at two and twenty on her cheeks for't,
Or Mercury unallayed, make blisters on it)
Would force a visit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And dare you deny her,
Or any else that I call mine? No more,
Attend her with all reverence and respect;
The want in you of manners, my lord may
Construe in me for malice. I will teach you
How to esteem and love the beauty he dotes on;
Prepare a banquet. Enter Martia and boy.
Madam, thus my duty
Stoops to the favour you vouchsafe your servant,
In honouring her house.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Is this in scorn?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No by the life of Virolet: give me leave
To swear by him, as by a saint I worship,
But am to know no further, my heart speaks that
My servants have been rude, and this boy (Doting
Upon my sorrows) hath forgotten his duty:
In which, that you may think I have no share,
Sirrah, upon your knees, desire her pardon.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I dare not disobey you.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Prithee rise,
My anger never looks so low: I thank you.
And will deserve it, if we may be private,
I came to see and speak with you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Be gone. Exit boy.
Good madam sit.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I rob you of your place then.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You have deserved a better, in my bed;
Make use of this too: now your pleasure lady.
If in your breaard there be a worthy pity,
That brings you for my comfort, you do nobly:
But if you come to triumph in your conquest,
Or tread on my calamities, 'twil wrong
Your other excellencies. Let it suffice,
That you alone enjoy the best of men,
And that I am forsaken.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: He the best?
The scum and shame of mankind.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Virolet, lady?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Blessed in him? I would my youth had chosen
Consuming fevers, bedrid age
For my companions, rather than a thing
To lay whose baseness open, would even poison
The tongue that speaks it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Certainly from you
At no part he deserves this; and I tell you,
Durst I pretend but the least title to him,
I should not hear this.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: He's an impudent villain,
Or a malicious wretch: to you ungrateful;
To me, beyond expression barbarous.
I more than hate him; from you, he deserves
A death most horrid: from me, to die for ever,
And know no end of torments. Would you have comfort?
Would you wash off the stain that sticks upon you,
In being refused? Would you redeem your fame,
Shipwrecked in his base wrongs? if you desire this,
It is not to be done with slavish suffering,
But by a noble anger, making way
To a most brave revenge, we may call justice;
Our injuries are equal; join with me then,
And share the honour.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I scarce understand you,
And know I shall be most unapt to learn
To hate the man I still must love and honour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This foolish dotage in soft-hearted women,
Makes proud men insolent: but take your way,
I'll run another course.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: As you are noble,
Deliver his offence.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: He has denied
The rites due to a wife.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O me most happy,
How largely am I paid for all my sufferings?
Most honest Virolet, thou just performer
Of all thy promises: I call to mind now,
When I was happy in those joys you speak of,
In a chaste bed, and warranted by law too,
He oft would swear, that if he should survive me,
(Which then I knew he wished not) never woman
Should taste of his embraces; this one act
Makes me again his debtor.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: And was this
The cause my youth and beauty were contemned?
If I sit down here! well —;

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I dare thy worst,
Plot what thou canst, my piety shall guard him
Against thy malice. Leave my house and quickly,
Thou wilt infect these innocent walls. By virtue
I will inform him of thy bloody purpose,
And turn it on thine own accursed head;
Believe't I will. Exit Juliana.

sp.speaker: Mart
sp.l: But 'tis not in thy power
To hinder what I have decreed against him.
He set myself to sale, and live a strumpet;
Forget my birth, my father, and his honour,
Rather than want an instrument to help meEnter Ronvere.
In my revenge. The captain of the guard;
Blessed opportunity courts me.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Sad and troubled?
How brave her anger shows? how it sets off
Her natural beauty? under what happy star
Was Virolet born, to be beloved and sought to,
By two incomparable women? Noblest lady,
I have heard your wrongs and pity them: and if
The service of my life could give me hope
To gain your favour, I should be most proud
To be commanded.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: 'Tis in you, my lord,
To make me your glad servant.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Name the means.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis not preferment, jewels, gold, or courtship.
He that desires to reap the harvest of
My youth and beauty, must begin in blood,
And right my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: I apprehend you madam,
And rest assured 'tis done; I am provided
Of instruments to fit you: to the King,
I'll instantly present you; if I fail,
He shall make good your aims: he's less than man,
That to achieve your favour, would not do
Deeds, friends would fear to put their agents to. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Quid invitus facis, non est scelus. 'tis an axiom,
Now whether willingly I have departed
With that I loved: with that, above her life
Loved me again, crowned me a happy husband,
Was full of children: her afflictions
That I begotten, that when our age must perish,
And all our painted frailties turn to ashes,
Then shall they stand and propagate our honours.
Whether this done, and taking to protection
A new strange beauty, it was a useful one:
How to my lust? if it be so, I am sinful;
And guilty of that crime I would fling from me.
Was there not in it this fair course of virtue?
This pious course, to save my friends, my country,
That even then had put on a mourning garment,
And wept the desolation of her children?
Her noblest children? Did not she thrust me on,
And to my duty clapped the spur of honour?
Was there a way, without this woman, left me
To bring 'em off? the marrying of this woman?
If not, why am I stung thus? why tormented?
Or had there been a wild desire joined with it,
How easily, both these, and all their beauties
Might I have made mine own? why am I touched thus,
Having performed the great redemption,
Both of my friends and family? fairly done it?
Without base and lascivious ends oh heaven,
Why am I still at war thus? why this a mischief,
That honesty and honour had propounded,
Ay, and absolved my tender will, and chid me,
Nay then unwillingly flung me on.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: He's here madam;
This is the melancholy walk he lives in,
And chooses ever to increase his sadness.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Stand by.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: 'Tis she: how I shake now and tremble?
The virtues of that mind are torments to me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sir, if my hated face shall stir your anger,
Or this forbidden path I tread in vex you;
My love, and fair obedience let behind me,
Your pardon asked, I shall return and bless you.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Pray stay a little, I delight to see you;
May not we yet, though fortune have divided us,
Ana set an envious stop between our pleasures,
Look thus one at another? sigh and weep thus?
And read in one another's eyes, the legends,
And wonders of our old loves? be not fearful,
Though you be now a saint, I may adore you:
May I not take this hand, and on it sacrifice
The sorrows of my heart? white seal of virtue.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My lord, you wrong your wedlock.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Were she here,
And with her all severe eyes to behold us,
We might do this; I might name Julian,
And to the reverence of that name, bow thus:
I might sigh Juliana, she was mine once;
But I too weak a guard for that great treasure —
And whilst she has a name, believe me lady,
This broken heart shall never want a sorrow.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Forget her sir, your honour now commands you
You are another's, keep those griefs for her,
She richly can reward 'em. I would have spoken with you

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: What is your will? for nothing you can ask,
So full of goodness are your words and meanings,
Must be denied: speak boldly.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I thank you sir. I come not
To beg, or flatter, only to be believed,
That I desire: for I shall tell a story,
So far from seeming truth, yet a most true one;
So horrible in nature, and so horrid;
So beyond wickedness, that when you hear it,
It must appear the practice of another,
The cast and malice of some one you have wronged much;
And me, you may imagine me accused to,
Unless you call to mind my daily sufferings;
The infinite obedience I have born you,
That hates all name and nature of revenge.
My love, that nothing but my death can sever,
Rather than hers I speak of.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Juliana,
To make a doubt of what you shall deliver,
After my full experience of your virtues,
Were to distrust a providence; to think you can lie,
Or being wronged, seek after foul repairings,
To forge a creed against my faith.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I must do so, for it concerns your life sir;
And if that word may stir you, hear and prosper:
I should be dumb else, were not you at stake here.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: What new friend have I found, that dares deliver
This loden trunk from his afflictions?
What pitying hand, of all that feels my miseries,
Brings such a benefit?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Be wise and manly,
And with your honour fall, when heaven shall call you,
Not by a hellish mischief.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Speak my blessed one,
How weak and poor I am, now she is from me?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Your wife.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Your wife.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Be tender of her, I shall believe else —

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I must be true: your ear, sir;
For 'tis so horrible, if the air catch it,
Into a thousand plagues, a thousand monsters,
It will disperse itself, and fright resistance,

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: She seek my life with you? make you her agent?
Another love? O speak but truth.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Be patient,
Dear as I love you, else I leave you wretched.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Forward, 'tis well, it shall be welcome to me;
I have lived too long, numbered too many days,
Yet never found the benefit of living;
Now when I come to reap it with my service,
And hunt for that my youth and honour aims at,
The sun sets on my fortune red and bloody,
And everlasting night begins to close me,
'Tis time to die. Enter Martia and Ronvere.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: She comes herself.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Believe lady,
And on this angel hand, your servant seals it,
You shall be mistress of your whole desires,
And what ye shall command.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Ha minion,
My precious dame, are you there? nay go forward,
Make your complaints, and pour out your feigned pities,
Slave, like to him you serve: I am the same still,
And what I purpose, let the world take witness,
Shall be so finished, and to such example,
Spite of your poor preventions; my dear gentleman,
My honourable man, are you there too?
You and your hot desire? Your mercy sir,
I had forgotten your greatness.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis not well lady.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Lord, how I hate this fellow now; how desperately
My stomach stands against him, this base fellow,
This gelded fool!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Did you never hear of modesty?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Yes, when I heard of you and so believed it,
Thou bloodless, brainless fool.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Thou despised fool,
Thou only sign of man, how I contemn thee!
Thou woven worthy in a piece of arras,
Fit only to enjoy a wall; thou beast
Beaten to use; have I preserved a beauty,
A youth, a love, to have my wishes blasted?
My dotings, and the joys I came to offer,
Must they be lost, and slighted by a dormouse?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Use more respect; and woman, 'twill become you;
At least, less tongue.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: He use all violence,
Let him look for't.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Dare you stain those beauties,
Those heavenly stamps, that raise men up to wonder,
With harsh and crooked motions? are you she
That overdid all ages, with your honour;
And in a little hour dare lose this triumph?
Is not this man your husband?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: He's my halter;
Which (Having sued my pardon) I fling off thus,
And with him all I brought him, but my anger;
Which I will nourish to the desolation,
Not only of his folly, but his friends,
And his whole name.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: 'Tis well, I have deserved it.
And if I were a woman, I would rail too.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Nature ne'er promised thee a thing so noble.
Take back your love, your vow, I give it freely;
I poorly scorn it; graze now where you please:
That that the dulness of thy soul neglected,
Kings sue for now. And mark me, Virolet;
Thou image of a man, observe my words well.
At such a bloody rate I'll sell this beauty,
This handsomeness thou scornest, and fling'st away,
Thy proud ungrateful life shall shake at: take your house;
The petty things you left me give another;
And last, take home your trinket: fare you well, sir.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: You have spoke like yourself;
You're a brave lady. Exeunt Ronvere and Martia.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why do you smile, sir?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: O my Juliana,
The happiness this woman's scorn has given me,
Makes me a man again; proclaims itself,
In such a general joy, through all my miseries,
That now methinks —

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Look to yourself dear sir,
And trifle not with danger, that attends you;
Be joyful when you're free.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Did you not hear liar?
She gave me back my vow, my love, my freedom;
I am free, free as air; and though tomorrow
Her bloody will meet with my life, and sink it,
And in her execution tear me piecemeal:
Yet have I time once more to meet my wishes,
Once more to embrace my best, my noblest, truest,
And time that's warranted.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Good sir, forbear it:
Though I confess, equal with your desires
My wishes rise, as covetous of your love,
And to as warm alarams spur my will to:
Yet pardon me, the seal oth' church dividing us,
And hanging like a threatening flame between us;
We must not meet, I dare not.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: That poor disjointing
That only strong necessity thrust on you,
Not crime, nor studied cause of mine: how sweetly,
And nobly I will bind again and cherish;
How I will recompense one dear embrace now,
One free affection! how I burn to meet it
Look now upon me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I behold you willingly,
And willingly would yield, but for my credit.
The love you first had was preserved with honour,
The last shall not cry whore; you shall not purchase
From me a pleasure, that have equally
Loved your fair fame as you, at such a rate:
Your honesty and virtue must be bankrupt,
If I had loved your lust, and not your lustre;
The glorious lustre of your matchless goodness,
I would compel you now to be! — forgive me,
Forgive me sir; how fondly still I love you!
Yet nobly too; make the way straight before me,
And let but holy Hymen once more guide me,
Under the axe, upon rack again,
Even in the bed of all afflictions,
Where nothing sings our nuptials but dire sorrows,
With all my youth and pleasure I'll embrace you,
Make tyranny and death stand still affrighted,
And at our meeting fowls amaze our mischiefs;
Till when, high heaven defend you, and peace guide you.
Be wise and manly, make your fate your own,
By being master of a providence,
That may control it.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Stay a little with me,
My thoughts have chid themselves: may I not kiss you?
Upon my truth I am honest.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I believe ye;
But yet what that may raise in both our fancies,
What issues such warm parents breed.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I obey you,
And take my leave as from the saint that keeps me.
I will be right again, and once more happy
In thy unimitable love.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I'll pray for ye,
And when you fall I have not long to follow. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter sesse, master, boatswain, and gunner, at one door: Martia and Ronvere, at another.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Now we have got free credit with the captain.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Soft, soft, he's here again: is not that lady —
Or have I lost mine eyes? A salt rheum seizes 'em;
But I should know that face.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Make him not madder,
Let him forget the woman; steer a-larboard .

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: He will not kill her.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Any thing he meets;
He's like a hornet now, he hums, and buzzes;
Nothing but blood and horror.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: I would save the lady,
For such another lady.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: There's the point;
And you know there want women of her mettle.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: 'Tis true, they bring such children now,
Such demilances,
Their father's socks will make them christening clothes.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: No more, they view us.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: You shall play a while,
And sun yourself in this felicity,
You shall you glorious whore; I know you still.
But I shall pick an hour when most securely —
I say no more.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Do you see those? those are they
Shall act your will; come hither my good fellows:
You are now the Kings. Are they not goodly fellows?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: They have bone enough, if they have stout heart to it.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Still the old wench.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Pray captain, let me ask you
What noble lady's that? 'tis a rude question,
But I desire to know.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: She is for the King, sir;
Let that suffice for answer.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Is she so sir?
In good time may she curse it.
Must I breed hackneys for his grace?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: What wouldst thou do
To merit such a lady's favour?

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: That can supply thy wants, and raise thy fortunes?

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Let her command, and see what I dare execute.
I keep my conscience here; if any man
Oppose her will, and she would have him humbled,
Whole families between her and her wishes —

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: We have seen bleeding throats sir, cities sacked,
And infants stuck upon their pikes.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Houses a fire, and handsome mothers weeping.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Which we have heaped upon the pile like sacrifices.
Churches and altars, priests and all devotions,
Tumbled together into one rude chaos.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: We know no fear sir, but want of employment.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Nor other faith but what our purses preach.
To gain our ends we can do any thing,
And turn our souls into a thousand figures;
But when we come to do —

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I like these fellows.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Be ready and wait here within this hour
I'll show you to the King, and he shall like ye:
And if you can devise some entertainment
To fill his mirth, such as your country uses,
Present it, and I'll see it graced.
After this comic scene we shall employ you,
For one must die.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: What is he sir? speak boldly,
For we dare boldly do.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: This lady's husband;
His name is Virolet.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: We shall dispatch it. Exit Martia, Ronvere
Oh damned, damned thing: a base whore first,
And then a murderer; I'll look to you.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Can she be grown so strange?

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: She has an itch;
I'll scratch you my dear daughter, I'll so claw you;
I'll curry your hot hide; married and honoured?
And turn those holy blessings into brothels?
Your beauty into blood? I'll hunt your hotness.
I'll hunt you like a train.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: We did all pity her.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Hang her, she is not worth man's memory;
She's false and base, and let her fright all storeys.
Well, though thou beest mine enemy, I'll right thee,
And right thee nobly.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Faith sir, since she must go,
Let's spare as few as may be.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: We'll take all,
And like a torrent sweep the slaves before us.
You dare endure the worst?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: You know our heart's sir,
And they shall bleed the last, erst we start from ye.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: We can but die, and ere we come to that,
We shall pick out some few examples for us.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Then wait the first occasion, and like Curtius,
I'll leap the gulf before you, fearless leap it:
Then follow me like men, and if our virtues
May boy our country up, and set her shining
In her first state; our fair revenges taken,
We have our noble ends, or else our ashes. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: As you are noble, keep me from discovery,
And let me only run a stranger's fortune;
For when the King shall find I am his daughter
He ever holds most ominous, and hates most:
With what eyes can he look, how entertain me,
But with his fears and cruelties?

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: I have found you,
Suspect not. I am bound to what you like best,
What you intend. I dare not be so curious
To question now; and what you are, lies hid here.
The King comes, make your fortune, I shall joy in't.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: All things are ready sir to make you merry,
And such a King you shall behold him now.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I long for't,
For I have need of mirth.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: The lady sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Now as I am a King, a sprightly beauty,
A goodly sweet aspect! my thanks Ronvere,
My best thanks; on your lips I seal your wishes,
Be what you can; imagine mine, and happy.
And now sit down and smile; come my Ascanio;
And let this monarch enter. Enter Sess. and Mr. Borisw. Gunner, and sailors.

sp.speaker: Rover.
sp.l: These are the Switzers.
I told your grace of.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Goodly promising fellows,
With faces to keep fools in awe, I like 'em;
Go guard the presence well, and do your duties,
Tomorrow I shall take a further view:

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: You shall sir,
Or I shall lose my will; how the whore's mounted?
How she sits throned? thou blazing muddy meteor,
That frightest the underworld, with lustful flashes,
How I shall dash thy flames? away, no word more:

div.stage: Ex. Sess. and his company. Flourish Cor.
Enter Villio, Castruchio, doctor, and a guard.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Now, here he comes in glory, be merry masters, meat conveyed away.
A banquet too?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: O, he must sit in state sir!

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.l: How rarely he is ushered? can he think now
He is a King indeed?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Mark but his countenance.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Let me have pleasures infinite, and to the height,
And women in abundance, many women,Enter ladies.
I will disport my grace,
Stand there and long for me.
What have ye brought me here? is this a feast
Fit for a prince? A mighty prince? are these things,
These preparations, ha?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: May it please your grace?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: It does not please my grace: where are the marchpanes,
The custards double royal, and the subtleties?
Why, what weak things are you to serve a prince thus?
Where be the delicates oth' earth and air?
The hidden secrets of the sea? am I a ploughman,
You pop me up with porridge? hang the cooks.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O most kingly:
What a majestic anger.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Give me some wine.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.l: He cools again now.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Fool, where are my players?
Let me have all in pomp; let 'em play some love matter,
To make the ladies itch, I'll be with you anon ladies;
You black eyes, I'll be with you
Give me some wine I say,
And let me have a masque of cuckolds enter:
Of mine own cuckolds,
And let 'em come in, peeping and rejoicing.
Just as I kiss their wives, and somewhat glorying.
Some wine I say, then for an excellent night-piece,
To show my glory to my loves, and minions:
I will have some great castle burned.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Hark you brother:
If that be to please these ladies, ten to one
The fire first takes upon your own, look to that;
Than you may show a night piece.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Where's this wine?
Why shall I choke? do ye long all to be tortured?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Why, what is this? why doctor,
Wine and water sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: 'Tis sovereign for your heat, you must endure it.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Most excellent to cool your nigh-piece sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: You are of a high and choleric complexion,
And you must have alleys.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Shall I have no sheer wine then?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Not for a world: I tender your dear life sir;
And he is no faithful subject —

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: No, by no means:
Of this you may drink; and never hang, nor quarter,
Nor never whip the fool, this liquours merciful.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I will sit down and eat then: Kings when they're hungry,
May eat I hope.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Yes, but they eat discreetly.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Come, taste this dish, and cut me liberally;
I like sauce well.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Fie 'tis too hot sir:
Too deeply seasoned with the spice, away with 't,
You must acquaint your stomach with those diets
Are temperately nourishing.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: But pray stay doctor,
And let me have my meat again.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: By no means:
I have a charge concerns my life.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: No meat neither;
Do Kings never eat doctor?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Very little sir.
And that too very choice.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Your King never sleeps brother,
He must not sleep, his cares still keep him waking.
Now he that eats and drinks much, is a dormouse;
The third part of a wafer, is a weeks diet.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Appoint me something then.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: This I feel good,
But it melts too suddenly; yet, how, that gone too! take away.
Ye are not mad! I charge you:

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: For your health sir,
A little quickens nature, much depresses.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Eat nothing for my health? that's a new diet;
Let me have something, something has some savour.
Why thou uncourteous doctor, shall I hang thee?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: 'Tis better sir, than I should let you surfeit;
My death were nothing.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: To lose a King, were terrible.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Nay, then I'll carve myself, I'll stay no ceremonies.
This is a partridge pie, I am sure that's nourishing,
Or Galen is an ass: 'tis rarely seasoned:
Ha doctor have I hit right? A mark, a mark there?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: What ails thy grace?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Retrieve those partridges.
Or as I am a King —

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Pray sir be patient,
They are flown too far.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: These are breathed pies an't please you,
And your hawks are such buzzards.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: A King and have nothing.
Nor can have nothing!

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: What think you of pudding?
A pudding royal?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: To be royally starved,
Whip me this fool to death; he is a blockhead.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Let 'em think they whip me, as we think you a King:
'Twill be enough.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: As for you dainty doctor, the table taken away,
All gone, all snatched away, and I unsatisfied,
Without my wits being a King and hungry?
Suffer but this thy treason? I tell thee doctor,
I tell it thee, in earnest, and in anger,
I am damnably hungry, my very grace is hungry.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: A hungry grace is fittest to no meal sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Some two hours hence, you shall see more: but still sir,
You must retain a strict and excellent diet.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: It sharpens you, and makes your wit so poignant,
Your very words will kill.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: A bit of marmalade
No bigger than a pease.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: And that well buttered,
The air thrice purified, and three times spirited,
Becomes a King: your rare conserve of nothing
Breeds no offence.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Am I turned King chameleon,
And keep my court ith' air?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: They vex him cruelly.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.l: In two days more they'll starve him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Now the women, there's no food left but they.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.l: They'll prove small nourishment.
Yet has another stomach and a great one,
I see by his eye.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I'll have mine own power here;
Mine own authority; I need no tutor.
Doctor this is no diet.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: It may be sir

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: By’r lady, it may turn to a dry diet;
And how thy grace, will ward that —

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Stand off doctor;
And talk to those that want faith,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Hot and mighty.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.l: He will cool apace, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Fair, plump, and red,
A forehead high; an eye revives the dead;
A lip like ripest fruit, inviting still.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: But oh, the rushy well, below the hill,
Take heed of that, for though it never fail
Take heed I say, for thereby hangs a tail.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I'll get ye all with child.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: With one child brother,
So many men in a blue coat.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Had I fed well.
And drank good store of wine, ye had been blessed all,
Blessed all with double births; come kiss me greedily,
And think no more upon your foolish husbands,
They are transitory things: a King's fame meets you,

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Vanish away. Ex. women.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: How, they gone too? my guard there:
Take me this devil doctor, and that fool there,
And sow 'em in a sack; bring back the women,
The lovely women, drown these rogues or hang 'em.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.l: He is in earnest sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: In serious earnest,Enter Sess. master, Boatsw. Gunner and sailors.
I missed needs take him off.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Now, now be free.
Now liberty, now countrymen, shake from ye
The tyrant's yoke.
All liberty, liberty, liberty.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Treason, treason, treason.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: We are betrayed, fly to the town, cry treason,
And raise our faithful friends; oh my Ascanio.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Make haste, we have way enough.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: Treason, treason. Ex. Fer. Asca. and guard.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Spare none, put all to th' sword: a vengeance shake thee;
Art thou turned King again?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I am a rascal:
Spare me but this time, if ever I see King more,
Or once believe in King ▪

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: The ports are ours.
The treasure and the port, fight bravely gentlemen;
Cry to the town, cry liberty and honour;
Waken their persecuted souls, cry loudly,One of crying liberty and freedom.
We'll share the wealth among ye.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Do you hear captain?
If ever you hear me, name a King.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: You shall not.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Or though I live under one, obey him.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: This rogue again.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Away with him good gunner.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Why look ye sir? I'll put you to no charge;
I'll never eat.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: I'll take a course, you shall not.
Come, no more words. Enter Boatsw.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Say nothing when you kill me.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: He's taken to the tower's strength;
Now stand sure gentlemen.
We have him in a pen, he cannot scape us,
The rest oth' castle's ours; liberty, liberty:
What is this city up?

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: They are up and glorious,
And rolling like a storm they come; their tents
Ring nothing but liberty and freedom.
The women are in arms too.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Let 'em come all.
Honour and liberty.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Honour and liberty. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: This woman's threats, her eyes, even red with fury
Which like prodigious meteors, foretold
Assured destruction, are still before me.
Besides I know such natures unacquainted
With any mean, or in their love, or hatred,
And she that dared all dangers to possess him,
Will check at nothing, to revenge the loss
Of what she held so dear, I first discovered
Her bloody purposes, which she made good,
And openly professed 'em; that in me
Was but a cold affection; charity
Commands so much to all; for Virolet
Methinks I should forget my sex's weakness,
Rise up, and dare beyond a woman's strength;
Then do, not counsel: he is too secure,
And in my judgement, 'twere a greater service
To free him from a deadly enemy,
Then to get him a friend. I undertook too,
To cross her plots, opposed my piety,
Against her malice; and shall virtue suffer?
No Martia, were't thou here equally armed,
I have a cause, spite of thy masculine breeding,
That would assure the victory: my angel
Direct and help me. Enter Virolet, like Ronvere.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: The state in combustion,
Part of the citadel forced, the treasure seized on;
The guards corrupted, arm themselves against
Their late protected master; Ferrant fled too,
And with small strength, into the castle's tower,
The only Aventine, that now is left him?
And yet the undertakers, nay, performers,
Of such a brave and glorious enterprise,
Are yet unknown: they did proceed like men,
I like a child; and had I never trusted
So deep a practice unto shallow fools,
Besides my soul's peace, in my Juliana,
The honour of this action had been mine,
In which, accursed, I now can claim no share.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ronvere! 'tis he, a thing, next to the devil
I most detest, and like him terrible;
Martia's right hand, the instrument I fear too,
That is to put her bloody will into act.
Have I not will enough, and cause too mighty?
Weak women's fear, fly from me.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Sure this habit,
This likeness to ronvere which I have studied,
Either admits me safe to my design,
Which I too cowardly have halted after,
And suffered to be ravished from my glory;
Or sinks me and my miseries together;
Either concludes me happy.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He stands musing,
Some mischief is now hatching:
In the full meditation, of his wickedness,
I'll sink his cursed soul: guide my hand heaven,
And to my tender arm give strength and fortune,
That I may do a pious deed all ages
Shall bless my name for; all remembrance crown me.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: It shall be so.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It shall not, take that token,
And bear it the lustful arms of Martia,
Tell her, for Virolet's dear sake, I sent it.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: O I am happy, let me see thee,
That I may bless the hand that gave me liberty,
Oh courteous hand, nay, thou hast done most nobly,
And heaven has guided thee, 'twas their great justice;
Oh blessed wound, that I could come to kiss thee!
How beautiful, and sweet thou showest!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Sigh not,
Nor weep not dear, shed not those sovereign balsams
Into my blood; which must recover me;
Then I shall live again, to do a mischief,
Against the mightiness of love and virtue,
Some base unhallowed hand shall rob thy right off.
Help me, I faint: so.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O unhappy wench!
How has my zeal abused me? you that guard virtue,
Were ye asleep? or do you laugh at innocence?
You suffered this mistake? O my dear Virolet!
An everlasting curse follow that form
I struck thee in his name ever blasted;
For his accursed shadow has betrayed
The sweetness of all youth, the nobleness,
The honour, and the valour; withered for ever
The beauty and the bravery of all mankind:
Oh my dull, devils eyes.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I do forgive you,
By this, and this I do; I know you were cozened;
The shadow of Ronvere, I know you aimed at,
And not at me; but 'twas most necessary,
I should be struck, some hand above directed you,
For Juliana could not show her justice
Without depriving high heaven of his glory,
Or any subject fit for her, but Virolet;
Forgive me too, and take my last breath sweet one,
This the new marriage of our souls together;
Think of me Juliana, but not often,
For fear my faults should burden your affections,
Pray for me, for I faint.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: O stay a little,
A little little sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Fie Juliana.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Shall I outlive the virtue, I have murdered?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Hold, or thou hatest my peace; give me the dagger;
On your obedience, and your love, deliver it.
If you do thus, we shall not meet in heaven sweet;
No guilty blood comes there; kill your intentions,
And than you conquer: there where I am going,
Would you not meet me dear?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: And still love me?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And still behold you.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Live then till heaven calls you,
Then ripe and full of sweetness you rise sainted.
Then I that went before you to prepare,
Shall meet and welcome you, and daily court you
With hymns of holy love — I go out,
Give me your hand, farewell, in peace farewell,
Remember me, farewell.Dies.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sleep you sweet glasses,
An everlasting slumber crown those crystals,
All my delight adieu, farewell, dear Virolet,
Dear, dear, most dear; oh I can weep no more,
My body now is fire, and all consuming,
Here will I sit, forget the world, and all things,
And only wait what heaven shall turn me to,
For now methinks , I should not live,She sits down.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: O my sweet daughter,
The work is finished now, I promised thee:
Here are thy virtues showed, here registered,
And here shall live for ever.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Blot it, burn it.
I have no virtue, hateful I am as hell is.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Is not this Virolet?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Ask no more questions,
Mistaking him, I killed him.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: O my son,
Nature turns to my heart again, my dear son,
Son of my age, wouldst thou go out so quickly?
So poorly take thy leave, and never see me?
Was this a kind stroke daughter? could you love him?
Honour his father, and so deadly strike him?
O withered timeless youth, are all thy promises,
Thy goodly growth of honours come to this?
Do I halt still ith' world, and trouble nature,
When her main pieces founder, and fail daily?
Boy he does weep certain: what bodies that lies by him?
How do you sir?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: O look there Lucio,
Thy master, thy best master.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Woe is me.
They have killed him, slain him basely, oh my master,

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Well daughter well; what heart you had to do this;
I know he did you wrong; but 'twas his fortune,
And not his fault, for my sake that have loved you,
But I see now, you scorn me too.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: O mistress?
Can you sit there, and his cold body breathless?
Basely upon the earth?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Let her alone boy,
She glories in his end.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You shall not sit here,
And suffer him you loved - ha; good sir come hither,
Come hither quickly, heave her up; oh heaven sir,
Oh God, my heart, she's cold; cold and stiff too.
Stiff as a stake, she's dead.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: She's gone, ne re bend her,
I know her heart, she could not want his company:
Blessing go with thy soul, sweet angels shadow it
Oh, that I were the third now, what a happiness?
But I must live, to see you laid in earth both,
Then build a chapel to your memories,
Where all my wealth shall fashion out your stories.
Then dig a little grave besides, and all's done.
How sweet she looks, her eyes are open smiling,
I thought she had been alive; you are my charge sir,
And amongst you, I'll see his goods distributed.
Take up the bodies, mourn in heart my friends,
You have lost two noble succours; follow me,
And thou sad country, weep this misery. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Sess. boitswaine, master, gunner, citizens, and soldiers, as many as may be.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Keep the ports strongly manned, and let none enter,
But such as are known patriots.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Liberty, liberty.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: 'Tis a substantial thing, and not a word
You men of Naples, which if once taken from us,
All other blessings leave us; 'tis a jewel
Worth purchasing, at the dear rate of life,
And so to be defended. O remember
What you have suffered, since you parted with it;
And if again you wish not to be slaves,
And properties to Ferrand's pride and lust,
Take noble courage, and make perfect what
Is happily begun.

sp.speaker: 1. Citizen
sp.l: Our great preserver,
You have enfranchised us, from wretched bondage.

sp.speaker: 2. Citizen
sp.l: And might be known, to whom we owe our freedom,
We to the death would follow him.

sp.speaker: 3. Citizen
sp.l: Make him King,
The tyrant once removed.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: That's not my end.
'Twas not ambition that brought me hither,
With these my faithful friends, nor hope of spoil;
For when we did possess the tyrant's treasure,
By force extorted from you, and employed
To load you with most miserable thraldom,
We did not make it ours, but with it purchased
The help of these, to get you liberty,
That for the same price kept you in subjection.
Nor are we Switzers, worthy countrymen,
But Neapolitans; now eye me well:
And though the reverend emblems of mine age,
My silver locks are shorn, my beard cut off,
Partaking yet of an adulterate colour;
Though 14. years you have not seen this face,
You may remember it, and call to mind,
There was a Duke of Sess, a much wronged prince,
Wronged by this tyrant Ferrand.

sp.speaker: 1. Citizen
sp.l: Now I know him.

sp.speaker: 2. Citizen
sp.l: 'Tis he, long live the Duke of Sess.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: I thank you.
The injuries I received, I must confess,
Made me forget the love I owed this country,
For which I hope, I have given satisfaction,
In being the first that stirred, to give it freedom;
And with your loves and furtherance, will call back,
Long banished peace, and plenty, to this people;

sp.speaker: 2. Citizen
sp.l: Lead where you please, we'll follow.

sp.speaker: 1. Citizen
sp.l: Dare all dangers.

div.stage: Enter Pandulf, the bodies of Virolet, and Juliana, upon a hearse.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: What solemn funeral's this?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: There rest a while,
And if't be possible there can be added
Wings to your swift desire of just revenge,
Hear, (If my tears will give way to my words)
In brief a most sad story.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Speak, what are they?
I know thee well Pandulfe.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: My best lord?
As far as sorrow will give leave, most welcome;
This Virolet was, and but a son of mine,
I might say, the most hopeful of our gentry;
And though unfortunate, never ignoble:
But I'll speak him no further. Look on this,
This face, that in a savage would move pity,
The wonder of her sex; and having said
'Tis Juliana, eloquence will want words
To set out her deservings; this blessed lady
That did endure the rack, to save her husband,
That husband, who, in being forced to leave her,
Endured a thousand tortures; by what practice,
I know not, (Burr 'twas sure a cunning one)
Are made, the last I hope, but sad examples
Of Ferrand's tyranny. Convey the bodies hence.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Express your sorrow
In your revenge, not tears, my worthy soldiers:
That fertile earth, that teemed so many children,
To feed his cruelty, in her wounded womb,
Can hardly now receive 'em.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: We are cold,
Cold walls shall not keep him from us.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Were he covered with mountains, and room only for a
Bullet to be sent level at him, I would speed him.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Let's scale this petty tower; at sea we are falcons,
And fly unto the main top in a moment.
What then can stop us here?

sp.speaker: 1 citizen
sp.l: We'll tear him piecemeal.

sp.speaker: 2 citizen
sp.l: Or eat a passage to him.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Let discretion
Direct your anger; that's a victory,
Which is got with least loss, let us make ours such:
And therefore friends, while we hold parley here,
Raise your scalado, on the other side,
But entered weak, your sufferings. Ex. Saylors and soldiers.

sp.speaker: 1 citizen
sp.l: In our wrongs.
There was no mean.

sp.speaker: 2 citizen
sp.l: Nor in our full revenge
Will we know any.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Be appeased good man,
No sorrow can redeem them from death's prison;
What his inevitable hand hath seized on,
The world cannot recover. All the comfort
That I can give to you, is to see vengeance
Poured dreadfully upon the author's head,
Of which their ashes may be sensible,
That have fallen by him.Sound a parley.

div.stage: Enter Ferrand, Martia, Ascanio, and Ronvere, above.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: They appear.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Tis not that we esteem rebellious traitors
Worthy an answer to their proudest summons
That we vouchsafe our presence; or to exchange
One syllable with 'em: but to let such know,
Though circled round with treason, all points bent
As to their centre at my heart, 'tis free,
Free from fear villains, and in this weak tower
Ferrand commands as absolute, as when
He trod upon your necks, and as much scorns you.
And when the sun of majesty shall break through
The clouds of your rebellion, every beam
Instead of comfortable heat, shall send
Consuming plagues among you; and you call
That government which you termed tyrannous
Hereafter, gentle.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Flatter not thyself
With these deluding hopes, thou cruel beast,
Thou art ith' toil, and the glad huntsman prouder,
By whom thou art taken, of his prey, than if
(Like thee) he should command, and spoil his forest.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: To thy horror, Duke of Sesse.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The devil.

sp.speaker: Sess.
sp.l: Reserved for thy damnation.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Why shakes my love?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: O I am lost for ever;
Mountains divide me from him; some kind hand
Prevent our fearful meeting: or lead me
To the steep rock, whose rugged brows are bent
Upon the swelling main; there let me hide me:
And as our bodies then shall be divided,
May our souls never meet.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Whence grows this, sweetest?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There are a thousand furies in his looks;
And in his deadly silence more loud horror,
Then when in hell the tortured and tormentors
Contend whose shrieks are greater. Wretched me!
It is my father.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Yes, and I will own her, sir,
Till my revenge. It is my daughter, Ferrand;
My daughter, thou hast whored.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I triumph in it:
To know she's thine, affords me more true pleasure,
Than the act gave me, when even at the height,
I cracked her virgin zone. Her shame dwell on thee,
And all thy family; may they never know
A female issue, but a whore, Ascanio.
Ronvere, look cheerfully; be thou a man too,
And learn of me to die. That we might fall,
And in our ruins swallow up this kingdom,
Nay the whole world, and make a second chaos.
And if from thence a new beginning rise,
Be it recorded this did end with us;
And from our dust hath embryon.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: I lived with you,
And will die with you; your example makes me
Equally bold.

sp.speaker: Ase
sp.l: And I resolved to bear
Whate'er my fate appoints me.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: They are ours,
Now to the spoil.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Pity the lady; to all else be deafed. Exeunt.
Within, kill, kill, kill. Alarum, Flo. trumpets.

div.stage: Enter Sesse with ferrands head, the citizens, master, boteswain, gunner, soldiers, bringing in Ascanio and Martia.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Cruel beginnings meet with cruel ends;
And the best sacrifice to heaven for peace,
Is tyrant's blood: and those that stuck fast to him,
Fleshed instruments in his commands to mischief,
With him dispatched.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: They are all cut off.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Thanks to the Duke of Sesse.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Pay that to heaven,
And for a general joy, give general thanks:
For blessings ne'er descend from heaven, but when
A grateful sacrifice ascends from men.
To your devotion; leave me; there's a scene,
Which I would act alone; yet you may stay,
For wanting just spectators, 'twill be nothing.
The rest forbear me.

sp.speaker: Citizens.
sp.l: Liberty liberty, liberty.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I would I were as far beneath the centre,
As now I stand above it; how I tremble!
Thrice happy they that died; I dying live
To stand the whirlwind of a father's fury.
Now it moves towards me.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Thou, I want a name,
By which to style thee: all articulate sounds
That do express the mischief of vile woman,
That are, or have been, or shall be, are weak
To speak thee to the height. Witch, parricide,
For thou, in taking leave of modesty,
Hast killed thy father, and his honour lost;
He's but a walking shadow, to torment thee.
To leave, and rob thy father; then set free
His foes, whose slavery he did prefer
Above all treasure, was a strong defeasance
To cut off, even the surest bonds of mercy.
After all this, having given up thyself,
Like to a sensual beast, a slave to lust,
To play the whore, and then (High heaven it racks me)
To find out none to quench thy appetite,
But the most cruel King, whom next to hell,
Thy father hated; and whose black embraces
Thou shouldst have fled from, as the whips of furies;
What canst thou look for?

div.stage: Enter Pandulph, and bodies born on the hearse.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Death; and 'tis not in you
To hurt me further: my old resolution,
Take now the place of fear; in this I lived,
In this I'll die, your daughter.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Look but here;
You had, I know, a guilty hand in this;
Repent it lady.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Juliana dead?
And Virolet?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: By her unwilling hand.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Fates you are equal. What can now fall on me,
That I will shrink at? now unmoved I dare
Look on your anger, and not bend a knee
To ask your pardon: let your rage run higher
Than billows raised up by a violent tempest,
And be as that is, deaf to all entreaties:
They are dead, and I prepared; for in their fall
All my desires are summed up.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Impudent too?
Die in it wretch.

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: Stay sir. Botsw. kills her.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: How dar'st thou villain,
Snatch from my sword the honour of my justice?

sp.speaker: Boatswain
sp.l: I never did you better service sir,
Yet have been ever faithful. I confess
That she deserved to die; but by whose hand?
Not by a father's. Double all her guilt,
It could not make you innocent, had you done it.
In me 'tis murder, in you 'twere a crime
Heaven could not pardon. Witness that I love you,
And in that love I did it.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: Thou art noble,
I thank thee for't; the thought of her die with her.

sp.speaker: Ascan.
sp.l: My turn is next: since she could find no mercy,
What am I to expect?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: With one voice, sir,
The citizens salute you, with the style
Of King of Naples.

sp.speaker: Ses.
sp.l: I must be excused,
The burden is too heavy for my shoulder,
Bestow it where 'tis due. Stand forth Ascanio,
It does belong to you; live long and wear it,
And warned by the example of your uncle,
Learn that you are to govern men, not beasts:
And that it is a most improvident head,
That strives to hurt the limbs that do support it.
Give burial to the dead; for me, and mine,
We will again to sea, and never know,
The place, which in my birth first gave me woe. Exeunt.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
